Bit.Trip Runner - Short ReviewBit.Trip Runner is a challenging rhythm platforming game that has a good soundtrack, but is essentially a game of trial and error. If you've played "The Impossible Game" and liked it, then you'll probably enjoy this as well. Although if you're prone to raging, then expect to rage a lot; especially if you like to go for that 100%.Pros:► Challenging and fun platformer► Great music► Responsive controlsCons:► Basically a game of trial and error; requires memorizing levels and hitting your marks► Hit boxes might register a hit even if you don't appear to collide with it► Only the zones are unique in terms of aesthetics, and there are only 3 of them.► No checkpoints during a level, so you'll need to pick up everything again after messing upHit / Miss:N/APersonal Rating:Avoid at all costsPick up during a saleWorth PlayingMust Play

content:
Posted: February 18, 2014
												I'm torn between recommending this game and recommending against it. Ultimately, I recommend against buying it.Pros:- The game has a wonderful and cohesive visual and auditory aesthetic.  The levels convey a compelling liveliness and otherworldliness.  The obstacles, enemies, and background "creatures" are inventive and cool-looking. I wish I could go explore the background with Commander Video.- The music is great.  I actually bought the album of the band that did the opening credits theme (Anamanaguchi) after hearing it in this game.- The mechanics are pretty predictable. It's obvious when you need to jump, smash, etc, although sometimes certain elements can get muddled by everything else going on around it.- It has achievements, and I like achievements, because I'm kinda OCD.- It has Steam cloud sync, because it's 2014.Cons:- It's billed as a rhythmic platformer, but falls short on both counts. As a platformer it's dull and the controls are tight. It requires rote memorization in many places rather than reliance on reflexes.  As a rhythmic game it falls short because the beats of the songs actually throw you off and aren't very well-timed to what you're supposed to be doing.  Rhythmic platformers must be pretty difficult to design because they require absolute integration in the spatial and time dimensions, but when the designers fail it actually makes the game less intuitive and more frustrating.- At times it seems like my character didn't actually collide with an object, but it registers a hit, sending me back to the beginning of the level. Seems like there's fudgy hitboxes. A game like this requires skintight hitboxes.- Just because it's hard doesn't make it fun. The designers deliberately made the game very hard by the exclusion of checkpoints.  You could call this "sadistic" or say it's meant to attract only the most diehard platformer fans (of which I am one), but it makes the game inaccessible and artificially extends the playtime. It's a crutch you see used a lot in indie platformers these days. Super Meat Boy was exceptionally hard but had an enormous amount of depth. Bit.Trip Runner is actually a pretty short and shallow experience if you add checkpoints.  - Since this is a rhythmic platformer, a large part of the game experience is enjoying the music. But it's incredibly difficult to even get past the first world (of three total), and you don't really hear different music until then.  By the time I got there I was so ♥♥♥♥ing tired of the music in the first world I never want to play it again. Contrast that to Electronic Super Joy, 140, and Super Meat Boy, where I frequently go back and play levels just to hear the music.- You have to focus so much on timing your movements that - Autoscroll on every level kinda sucks in platformers. That's probably a controversial statement, but it's what I think. Oh, and while I'm at it, Metallica's "And Justice for All..." is their best.- The boss battles are inventive, but by the 100th time I tried to beat the first world boss I was ♥♥♥♥ing bored out of my mind. I actually had to write down the order of what comes at me in order to beat it. This isn't Calculus. I shouldn't have to take notes.I think the cons outweigh the pros, so I can't recommend this one. But, if you like really hard platformers with good music and don't mind nearly-endless repetition, you'll probably enjoy it.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2013
												Frustration deluxe.Ok so the game and concept is simple, your character constantly run to the right and you have to slide, jump, kick, bounce, reflect or any of these combinations together to get to the end of the level. The music that plays in the background helps you keep the pace somewhat and you can probably blindfold this game if you memorize it completely.But the bad thing about the game, is that you have one try.If you fail in any way, you will start at the beginning of the level. The first few levels are easy, but the further in you get into a chapter, the levels get both longer and more complicated, some lasting up to 4-5 minutes. So the game turns into a game or memorizing every little thing, you have to remember which buttons to press and for how long to press them as well, some things you get barely no warning of at all so the first time you get there, you will die.Fun.So the game itself is pretty fun, except the lack of checkpoints, which makes it extremely frustrating instead.Graphics: It’s pretty if you like this 3d-pixel environment. It works well I think. :)Things kind of tend to blur together at times, but might be intentional to make it harder.Technically I had no real hiccups, though I experienced some light lags at times, but think it might be my computer instead of the game. 99% of the time it was smooth sailing.So should you buy this? Well, I don’t know, some might like this a lot, perfecting levels is a wonderful feeling, but if you are forced to perfect them… Well, it just sucks the fun out of a game. If you don’t mind this, then you should probably buy it. It is a good game in the bottom, but the frustrating stuff really tended to get in the way for me.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
												This game is fun and addicting, but it has some major flaws.First of all, the difficulty curve in this game is pretty wonky. Now, I'm not sure if this is because I got used to the game as I progressed, but I felt that some of the later stages (especially from world 2) were incredibly easy when compared to the earlier ones. The difficulty ramps up again towards the end, but you'll still find that it varies greatly from stage to stage instead of following a steadily rising curve as you would expect.Second, while the level design will overall test your skills and reflexes, it can be a bit repetitive and sometimes very frustrating. The game will resort to artificial methods of increasing the difficulty by placing obstacles and items at very awkward positions, and since a single mistake will take you back to the beginning of the stage, that translates into annoying trial-and-error gameplay. If you don't mind having your patience tested, then you should do just fine.And last but not least, the game has a motion blur effect that, as far as I know, cannot be disabled. I guess they chose to use this effect to give a good sense of speed and movement, but it would have been nice to include an option to disable it. Not only that effect is going to tire out your eyes  if play this game for long periods of time, but it might also cause you to fail at certain points of the game because the game's art style doesn't stand out very much — obstacles and items tend to blend in with each other, it's hard to tell them apart sometimes, and the continuous blur doesn't help one bit.The game is still worth a shot, if you're feeling adventurous. The difficulty is insane and rage-quit inducing, and finishing a tough stage can be very satisfying. Sadly, however, I personally think that the flaws outweigh its qualities. I recommend you try the sequel, "Runner2", a much better game in pretty much every aspect.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												Very much on the fence on this one, but I'm going to have to come down on the side of not recommending this game. Bit Trip Runner is a scrolling rythm based platformer. The screen constantly scrolls to the right and as you run you have to jump, slide, kick and block your way through the level. It starts off great. Good music, tight controls, and bright colorful graphics put together an awesome presentation. As you pick up gold and "power ups" the music fills in and the your actions in the level fill in the background to the music. It's a cool effect. That for me was where the good times ended. Near the end of the first world, the game becomes brutally hard. There are no checkpoints in Bit.Trip Runner. One mistake will send you flying all the way back to the beginning of the level. You have no health so it's one hit and you die. With some levels over 3-4 min long, the constant act of being sent back to the start every time is annoying and gives you little chance to work on the one tough spot you're having a problem with.  And those tough spots? This game leaves very little to no room for error. You have to be precise. At least with games like Super Meat Boy, the level is very short. It lends itself well to quick deaths and restarts because you're working on the same area and you can go at your own pace. That's not the case here. I finally did beat this game, but my feeling was more relief than triumph. If you're hardcore into platformers you may enjoy it, but there are better titles out there.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												BIT.Trip Runner is a rhythmic, side-scrolling platformer.The player takes control of Commander Video, who will run endlessly until he reaches the end of each stage. You can have him jump and duck to avoid obstacles, kick certain obstacles out of the way, launch himself on springboards or deflect objects with a shield. If Commander Video impacts with an obstacle, the player is forced to repeat the entire stage from the beginning. The game consists of 3 themed worlds, each with 11 stages and a boss stage.Aside from the main objective of reaching the end of each stage, the player can also attempt to collect all items within each stage (score multipliers that increase the intensity of the music and particle effects, as well as gold bars). Completing a stage with every item collected will give a "Perfect" score and grant access to a bonus stage in the style of an old Atari game. The core mechanic is mostly the same in that you reach the end of the bonus collecting as much gold as you can while avoiding obstacles. Collecting all the gold within a bonus stage gives a "Double Perfect" score.Graphics are simple, most objects being composed of low-poly blocks with very basic textures. The overall visual aesthetic is competent, pulling off a retro-inspired look yet remaining in a 3D space, but the repetitiveness of playing stages consecutively undermines the appeal of the simplicity as there is very little visual variation between them. Audio quality is likewise competent and fitting to the overall theme, with the level designs reflecting the rhythm of the music to varying degrees, mixed in with suitable arcade sound effects. Unfortunately, this also suffers from monotony as you will hear a lot of the music repeated over and over as you progress, with only two unique songs for each of the three worlds (excluding boss stages, which again all share the same music) and none of the music is particularly good.The controls are tight and responsive, each stage is mostly a fluid experience with each button press feeling natural in time with the rhythm. Mistakes will be made but they rarely feel unfair, but the game is nonetheless totally unforgiving in that any mistake that causes an impact with an obstacle will cause Commander Video to fall right back to the start of the stage and do it all over again. Later stages may cause players to give up out of frustration, even on easy difficulty (which isn't actually easier at all).Completing a challenging stage gives great satisfaction and the motivation to carry on through the disappointingly bland presentation. It tests your skills and timing rather than relying on stats and/or making it too easy, but this will of course leave some people out of luck if they are finding it too difficult to continue past a certain point, because anything short of perfection will not allow for progression. Despite this, the difficulty curve is relatively steady from start to finish.BIT.Trip Runner is a fun game to play in short bursts, but due to the monotony of the visuals, audio and level design, would probably cause headaches and frustration if played for much longer durations.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2013
												This is a beautiful side scroller where you jump, slide and kick your way to make it through things. Did I mention that it automatically scrolls to the side? You really have no control over the movement, just the ability to jump over things, kick through them and slide under them. Seems simple enough. The jumping is not floaty at all and takes some true prescision. Even the simplest jump up stairs or jump over a chasm needs to be timed correctly.The music is also a stand out plus in the game even if it seems like there really aren't many songs. Just beats in the background. Every time you jump it makes a sound that adds to the melody. Every time you grab a + sign the beat amps up.Bit.Trip Runner is split into 3 episodes each with around 10 levels. Each level will have you trying to obtain + marks on your way to the end. A lot of levels seem like the level is really 1/4th the level and they just make you run it 4x in the level. You will come to know these levels VERY well, because the downside is if you bump into something you will be taken back all the way to the beginning of a level.If you are the type of person that loves timing games with beautiful backgrounds and good music then this game is for you. But I can't imagine after beating this game that I will ever play it again.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												If games had voices Bit.Trip Runner would be nothing but a prolonged maniacal laugh, over the casual-friendly endless runners that permeate the mobile game market, and you the player for your thousands of clumsy failed attempts to clear a level. Runner demands absolute perfection, and in returns provides one of the most precise and satisfying games to ever grace the genre.Although it bares many similarities to endless runners such as Canabalt, BTR is a far more deliberately structured experience than the many flash offerings available, and doesn't actually deserve to be called an endless runner as shares more in common with a rhythm game than anything else. Each enemy, obstacle, and jump is timed directly to the music playing behind it, an integral fact that is critical in landing your timing and predicting what is coming down the line. As you dodge these hurdles you in turn add your own portion of the soundtrack, fleshing out the melody and adding new layers to each track. Nailing a run perfectly is exhilarating, all the more so because doing so requires such finesse and determination.It should be noted and re-noted that BTR is a very, very hard game, perhaps the most difficult one in fact that I have ever successfully completed. It is brutally unforgiving from the onset and doesn't hesitate to send you right back to the start of the level over the tiniest slip-up. There are no checkpoints at any point in the game, and as levels become longer the trial and error design calls for some serious memorization and hand eye coordination.I don't doubt for a second that most will not complete the game, perhaps not even the first would. It's a grueling task that appeals to a specific sect of masochistic gamers which, although I personally love it to death, is the reason I simply cannot recommend the game to anyone who isn't ready for an immense challenge. Everyone else will find a far better time skipping straight to Runner 2, which is all around a much more easily enjoyable game regardless of skill level.Level variety is also a bit of a problem, as with only three different worlds you will be spending a lot of time looking at the same things, and overcoming the same obstacles. This isn't such a bad thing as the music and art are excellent across the board, but it did begin to wear on me after spending so long stuck in the same place. Another minor problem is that for the later two worlds the backgrounds become so congested, that they sometimes obscure obstacles coming toward you which is highly frustrating and one of the few parts of the game that just feels cheap.No matter these smaller problems I still adore Bit.Trip Runner. The way the music ties into the gameplay gives it a unique feel and keep the experience feeling fair no matter how often I failed at it. The electronic soundtrack perfectly complements the style of gameplay, and the way it all comes together is much more consistently great than likely any Bit.Trip game that came before it. There is something to be said for the difficulty turning many players away (and you would be right to do so if that isn't your cup of tea), but for those unafraid to attempt to conquer the laborious challenge it presents, Runner is easily worth a try and for provides a sense of personal accomplishment that other games can't.

number of helpful: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												BIT.TRIP RUNNER is an indie game that, like most indie games, will leave you either wanting more or wanting your money back. The game was developed by Gaijin Games for the Virtual Console on the Nintendo Wii in 2010, but was released on Steam in February 2011. BIT.TRIP RUNNER is a rhythm-style action plaformer that consist of a protagonist, Commander Video, on a 2D plane. The player controls Commander Video as he runs along the set track from left to right and controls when the character jumps, slides, and kicking. As you progress through the 36 levels in the game (three worlds, each consisting of 11 levels, plus a boss encounter stage), you collect powerups that increase the quality of the music that plays through each level. The game is notable for it's unique soundtrack, retro feel, and it's frustratingly difficult gameplay, as the current level is started over each time Commander Video runs into an obstacle that the player failed to acknowledge. The game forces a trial-and-error style of play, and in the end, it can hurt the experience. I myself found that I would get particularly frustrated on nearly every level that I played, as I would have to start the level over simply for pressing a button to early or too late. However, the game exceeds in rewarding the player, as the sense of accomplishment that comes from beating a particularly difficult level is unrivaled by most games that are released on the market today. BIT.TRIP RUNNER is a unique game that can be extremely rewarding, or absolutely crushing. Be warned: the game is not for everyone. While I didn't particularly enjoy BIT.TRIP RUNNER, it continues to be a game that is loved by the Indie community and the games that follow it only stand to be a testament to their devotion. A 5 out of 10. Authors Note - I, personally, did not enjoy BIT.TRIP RUNNER. I felt that it was too difficult for me and that it simply wasn't my type of game. However, I do highly recommend this game to any and all gamers that have yet to play it. It's a challenging experience that harkens back to the older days of retro gaming, and for that, I can honestly say that everybody should play these games, at least once.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
												BIT.TRIP RUNNER pushes the boundaries on sound design, gameplay, and atmosphere. Where should I start?Sound Design:The BIT.TRIP series is well known to be part of the "rhythm game" genre, so not surprisingly, the sound design is absolutely superb. You can tell how much dedication Gaijin Games put into this specific installment. Every obstacle you face has an associated tone that adds to the melody of the song, where collectable + signs give you a score boost and make the rhythm of the music more basey. Every + sign you collect, a robotic voice declares that you are "Mega", "Super", "Ultra", and finally "Extra", which really helps with my self esteem issues.Gameplay:Hence the name, BIT.TRIP RUNNER is about running. What the title fails to convey, however, is the sheer amount of dodging, blocking, ducking, and kicking you will be doing throughout your adventure. Some levels are easier than others, and there are many instances where there are massive difficulty spikes (*COUGH* ODYSSEY). The main objective is to dodge all enemies, but for all the completionists out there, every level has a certain number of gold bars, and you will score PERFECT on a level if you collect them all. If you accomplish that, you can even get a double PERFECT by getting all gold in the insanely difficult bonus levels that follow. What can be concluded from all this: Gaijin Games has a capitalist agenda that they're trying to push on the media.Atmosphere:Upon first analyzing the game, the graphic design is very jarring. Commander Video is a sprite, and yet the entire world is in 3D! Yet, it is that juxtaposition between his appearance and the world that allows us to appreciate the environment for what it is. Make the main character too realistic, and you would focus on him. Considering there is no dialogue in this game, much of its story and impressions rely on noticing subtle details in the background. Meat Boy even makes a cameo in one level! For this reason, I think it's simply genius that they made that gameplay choice.All in all, I think this game should be nominated for Game of the Year 2016. It's a must buy.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12
												This is like the Simon electronic memory game from the 80's except with better visuals, music, and an occasional chance to mitigate bad memory with hasty reflexes. That is to say: it's better than Simon, but that's a pretty low bar. The problem is that it passes itself off as a rhythm-platformer –– an acceptable label until the level length and difficulty becomes such that memorizing the hazards is the key to victory. "Okay, duck twice in row.. then 3 jumps and a kick and then...." forgetting makes you freeze and you plow into an obstacle.You might find this kind of misery to be something at which you could excel, and I'll grant that the gameplay has a certain appeal. But there are other misfires which prevent me from really recommending the title. One in particular: BIT.TRIP RUNNER places heavy emphasis on "perfect" completions of the levels (rewarding it with achievements and the like). Nabbing all the collectibles in a given level gives you subsequent access to a "retro level" –– an additional challenge postfixed to each normal level. If you mess up anything in one of these retro levels (which you most certainly will do), the game offers no chance to have another crack at it. It immediately queues up the next normal level and starts. If you want to attempt that particular retro level again, you must exit to the level select menu, choose the previous normal level you played, and complete that one with a perfect score to give you one additional shot at the retro stage. Having to repeatedly complete (perfectly, remember) one level to have individual chances at another will make you grind your teeth to powder. Is this negligence by the designers or leveraging time for difficulty (a member of the gaming Rogues Gallery)? Neither of those explanations is satisfactory.That's all to say, this game will make you mad. But I think it's often for the wrong reasons.edit - fixed a word

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												I've read many reviews about people comparing this game with its sequel, and basing this comparison to basically not recommending it.I'm in the point that I can comprehend both visions. Indeed, this game is unfair, the hitbox is confusing until the end, the lack of checkpoints makes it hardcore, it's more based on memory than reflexes, and as a rhythm game, it's basically a failure. Runner 2 fixes all that stuff, so it's logic that many people around here suggest you should avoid this game.BUT.I must remind you all that Runner 2 is actually the odd member of the family. Apart from it, ALL Bit.Trip games are this mercyless, and even more (in fact, the Runner games are the easiest ones from the franchise IMO). So Bit.Trip Runner is just another game similar to all those from the same company. It's not fair at all to compare it with a game that has very few in common if you look coldly. Personally, the Runner's games are the only ones from this franchise that I enjoyed. And if you have to choose one of them, it's just a matter of interests: if you wanna beat a real challenge and prove yourself you can face a hard game, try Runner 1; if you want to enjoy those kind of arcade games where you main purpose is avoiding things without getting frustrated, try Runner 2. I suggest playing both though. In conclusion, you'll read many positive and negative reviews, and all of them will be true. This game is simply not made for everybody, only for people who enjoys challenges from videogames, while its sequel is suitable for everybody.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
AUDIORhythmicVISUAL3D PixelDIFFICULTYToughVIBEPlatforming hellCRAVINGMusicON SALEOccasionallyPROS: A great addition to the musical-runner genre, and leads by example as to how these games should be made. Visuals are unique and highly-rewarding. Music when running at full speed in more active levels is fun. Teaches through gameplay rather than dialogue boxes, keeping the flow going.CONS: Very repetitive if being sent back is your worst nightmare in a game; one mistake and you're unceremoniously placed back at the beginning of the level. No checkpoints, no second-tries. Lots of artificial difficulty.WORTH: I see this game stagnating in people's inventories often. It's easy to open up, but hard to pick back up after the long breaks it ends up sending you on out of rage. If you don't have patience, you shouldn't pay full price.OVERALL: You may rage-quit, but you'll be back. They always come back.SCORE:6/10                                                                     Full Review Coming Soon

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Oh my this game is so good.  It's unforgivingly hard, even on Easy difficulty, but it's never unfair.  Every time I fail (and I fail over and over again) it never feels like the game cheated me out of victory, but that I needed to play better.  Further, I can't play this as a marathon play session.  After 10 or 15 minutes my concentration starts to break, I stop improving, and I have to quit for a while and come back later.  And I do keep coming back.As to what the game is actually like, the trailer video is a good representation.  If you see that and want to play, you won't be disappointed.  If you see it and aren't sure, maybe just watch some perfect runs on Youtube.  Different genres appeal to different people.The only difference between Normal and Easy is there are no coins to collect in Easy.  That's it, all the obstacles and platforming challenges remain.  In theory you could play through the game on Normal that way and just ignore all the coins to complete the levels more easily.  But there's so much to focus on that's harder than it seems, and removing the distraction does make a difference.And the difference between Normal and Perfect is you have to collect ALL the coins and other scoring opportunities in a level to pass it.  This is actually really helpful.  When you're trying for a perfect run on a level you don't have to fail on purpose and lose your momentum if you miss something.So the only reason to play the game on Normal is for the Braid achievement.  Otherwise I recommend switching between Easy to see the whole game (and make the Endure achievement easier) and Perfect for collecting all the things.  Beating a level on Normal doesn't feel quite as thrilling when you know you left some points behind.  (It still does feel pretty awesome though.  Just even more awesome when you get all the things.)The only misstep in the whole thing is Odyssey (stage 1.11).  And it's not bad, it's as great as everything.  But it may be the hardest stage in the game, and it feels like a wall to get stuck on compared to earlier and later advancement.  It seems to be included as early as it is not because of a difficulty progression, but because as you progress you are taught new skills, and Odyssey doesn't require abilities and tricks that later levels do.One final note -- other reviewers have talked about the artistic quality of the graphics and music.  But the level design throughout is art too, and a joy to experience.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												Tough side scrolling game. I'd call it a platformer, but when the screen continuously scrolls without you controlling it, it makes it rough to qualify it as a platformer, though it obviously resembles one. Some call it a rythmn game, and while it does utilize a rythmn of sorts, I found that it was just easy to play this game with the sound turned off as it was easy when the sound was on. Easy, isn't the correct word to describe this though, this game is incredibly difficult at times. The idea is to jump, block, slide, or kick your way through each level. If you die anywhere in the level you start all over. This makes it difficult on the long levels. The graphics work for the type of game that it is, though they will not attract many newcomers without the gamer feeling nostalgia for the retro graphics. This is a good game, just know that you may either smash your keyboard or lose some hair with the frustration that it can bring.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												Ok, as you can see this game called bit trip RUNNER is pretty much that, a platformer on rails where you dodge obstacles  and -only if you want to unlock everything like I did- collect floating gold bars, and not much else. This game works great, super fluid, and is compatible with a 360 controller, sadly that's the only thing that I can appreciate from it. Its funny because some people claim that this game is "hard" and "fast paced", and let me tell ya, is none of those1) Its not really hard, with some practice you will end up memorizing the secuence of the obstacles, you are just avoiding them without having control of your character, other than kicking, jumping, ducking, reflecting (you have some kind of orange bar that reflects only one kind of proyectile), or jumping higher from a spring, and thats one of the cheapest flaws in the game that makes it "hard". There are some kind of pink tiles that work like springs, all you have to do is press up or the Y button and you can jump higher than the regular jump, obviously there are sections that you need to do this in order to beat a level, how can you screw that up? usually you'll need to press the button right before you miss the pink tile because if you press it too early you'll land 3 pixels behind of the very spot you need to land on because, most of the time, in the spot where you should have landed there was a golden bar that you have to collect and if you landed right behind it you won't touch it and its game over for you if you're playing it on perfect difficulty and you lose whenever you miss anything you have to collect. Another cheap flaw is the perfect difficulty, because as I said before whenever you miss anything like the golden bar you lose, thankfully when that happens you can try again because it takes you BACK TO THE BEGINING of the level.Every.Time. This game wants you to be sooo perfect that when you press one button one instant before or after the instant the game wants or if you don't land on one magical pixel the game wants, hell even if you are almost half of a second late you lose and you have to restart the level at once. That's what make the game hard, because if you play it on normal or easy its pretty much, no, its the same crap, with the only difference of not having to collect EVERY GOLDEN BAR.2) fast paced? no, simple as that, this ain't sonic, is just commander video. You can see whats ahead you, unless you're playing the bonus stages where your field of view is reducedPeople claim that the gameplay is brilliant, I didn't find it like that, at all, not even close. This game gets repetitive in a few hours, there were times where I could tell that the developers recycle some sections in many levels, to the point that I could even guess the algorithm that dodges the obstaclesI gave this game and its sequel a chance, bought them during the sale so I did't spend too much money, but I was so dissapointed that I feel it would've been the same even if they were freeThen again, you can pretty much tell what kind of game it is ny just looking at it, but I saw some many positive reviews saiying that the gameplay is brilliant, fast paced, and unique. I bought that and ended up dissapointed because I found this game average at its best. Even at the end of the day I didn't expect too much from it, no matter how many people recommended it, but still deep inside I expected something at least better than what it looked like, and this wasn't the caseBit Trip Runner is a bad game? nah, its not, just because you see that red downvoting hand doesn't mean that this game sucks, not really. You may find it entertainingand all but thats about it, not a really memorable indie game tbhThis game took me around 30 hours to unlock everything, including the freaking achievements because whenever I buy a videogame I want to beat it and unlock everything that I can, and these achievements weren't that hard, just annoying, and made my experience way longer that it had to be, because I couldn't find any replay value, once you unlock everything that's it for this game, same thing happened me with the sequel. And speaking of which, people also claim that the sequel was uperior because they made runner "better" and with more variety, and the only variety there were some minimal thing that didn't make it harder, hell I thought it was way more easier since they made the hit detection more merciful on the sequel, because on the first runner whenever you thought you collected the golden bar you ended up losing because you missed by one pixel. The only variety on Runner 2 is that you can play as other characters and actually find alternative exits that you need to follow in order to unlock stuffBoss fights are pointless, they are basically an extra level for each zoneOne last thing, this game is supposed to be a rythm game but Guitar Hero was more of a rythm game than this, here you have a generic bgm for each zone (there are 3 zones with 12 levels each, including the "boss" level) and whenever you collect these red crosses the bgm changes a bit, and every obstacle that you dodge makes a silly sound. When you keep dodging the secuence it kind of plays a melody but it doesn't have that kind of an impact unlike GH, some people may find it charming but not meTL;DR meh, wouldn't reccomend this nor its sequelwant a hard game? Super Meat Boy

Product received for free
												I'm really not one for "runners" or difficult platformers and this game still has me hooked. Good challenge, awesome soundtrack, and a devlishly utilized aesthetic. I don't see myself growing to love this genre but all the BIT.TRIP games are all quality so it's no wonder I enjoy this. Yet another woefully neglected Humble Bundle game I took way to long to pick up in earnest.There are some disappointments, though. There's very often forced moments of rote memorization rather than reliance on reflex and skill. The "rhythm" component of this game is a bit of an undertone rather than a core component of the game as well. And worst of all, despite how lightweight it is, it still manages to drop some frames on my laptop gpu (Intel HD 3000) and turning off v-sync isn't quite an option due to how visually distracting it is. I honestly dont know what makes a good game in the genre, but those are some things I've noticed. Still a good play.

												Bit.Trip Runner is an insteresting rythem game featureing CommanderVideo. Jump and dodge your way through long roads, collect gold, and defeat some bosses. Stylized with classic 8-bit/3D combination, the game is fun and has some cool tunes to listen to. Although only containing 3 zones each with 11 challenges and a boss fight, it's also very difficult at times. number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												This is an semi-rhythm, auto-scrolling platformer where you time your actions to avoid death.  Your basic actions are jump, kick, block, and duck -- and combinations of those.  Pretty simple stuff, but the challenging part is to do this quickly without too much error.  This is really a test of hand-eye coordination and memory (due to the levels being the same each time).  Rhythm and music are a key part of this game, but the game also relies on non-rhythmic actions as well.  As for any negatives, I have read some complaints about levels not having check points.  The lack of level check points is actually part of the appeal!  But do consider that the levels take no more than three minutes to complete so it's not as if you are losing a lot of invested time here when you die.  And speaking of dying, you will die a lot but in a fun and challenging way.  In the end, this is one of those games that doesn't look all that fun until you actually play it.  I've fallen in love with this game, and indeed, it is highly addictive!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												It's Meh  I've heard lots of good things about this game, so I bought it during the Steam Winter Sale. I did not enjoy this game. At first, the game was pretty fun, and I liked it, though I noticed a delay from when I hit a key to when the game responded (I had no lag/framedrop during the time of play) so it made the game difficult to stay on beat, so I found myself starting over quite a bit. This could just be my keyboard, so I don't know. Also, there are no checkpoints. At all. So one little mistake, one little off-beat press of a button, and you are sent all the way back through that 5 minute level you just drudged through.  The game itself is a music/rythm platforming game, however I wouldn't call it a rythm game. It feels more like a memory game. Throughout the game, you must jump, kick, slide, bounce, and reflect to reach the end of the stage. The graphics made me felt like I was going crosseyed while I played, they look good, but they don't mix well with a moving foreground. It made it unenjoyable, and I got headaches from it. This, mixed with the whole jumping and kicking, made it nearly impossible for me to even see what was going on. The rounds would drag on, and on. So, I had to memorize the course, while the backround remains stationary with a moving foreground, with a delay on me hitting buttons.  Here is the most enjoying part. The music. I loved it, except, every time you die, you get sent back to the beginning. Meaning that the music starts over with it. So you will be hearing the same du-du-dun-dun-dun-du-dun ... du-du-dun-dun-dun-du-dun ... du-du-dun-dun-dun-du-dun over and over again. I know I said I loved the music, but I couldn't love it enough from the constant restarting. Also, a lot of the songs sound the same, the music is put together from you "staying on beat" with the music. Staying on beat is used loosely (see above paragraph). I liked this aspect, you were making the music as you played along. The music progressively got better and better as you played, unless you miss one of those power-ups that up you, and the music. That part bugged me, but it is my fault for not being good enough, it made me want to replay the level and try to hear the music to it's full potential.  The graphics, they are really good. It's a mix of a stationary backround and a moving foreground, which I hated, but even though I hated how they pulled it off, they looked very good. So credit where it's due.  So, to close this review, here are the pros and cons of this game.Pros:Good music, good graphics, fun to play, bonus levels are repetetive, but fun, a bit of replay value in there.Cons:Repetetive music, headache inducing graphics, late controls, lack of checkpoints makes the game very unforgiving, not a rythym but instead a memory game.   I did not enjoy BIT.TRIP RUNNER and I do not believe it is worth the $10 it is being sold for currently. I'm glad I paid for it during the sale for much, much, cheaper. I have no words for the sequel, as I have not played it. Some may find it okay, if they don't have the late controls or headaches, but I did not like BIT.TRIP RUNNER.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												BIT.TRIP RUNNER is a game that hails to the pre-NES gaming era. This game has the player performing well timed jumps, slides and other moves, usually in a rhythmic fashion, to collect gold bars and avoid obstacles. BIT.TRIP RUNNER was a well received game and it seems that this game has a lot of indie cred but my experience playing this game contrasted to what I hear in the reviews has me wondering if I'm playing the right game or if I need to drill down into an option menu somewhere to enable the good content. The art style is distinctive and appealing and the game itself does have it's moments, however it forces you to endure quite a bit of tedium to get to a meager portion of enjoyable gameplay. BIT.TRIP RUNNER is a game that requires very price timing and rythmn and a single half-second delay will mean restarting the level in most cases. The first 20 seconds or so of each level will insult you by being boring and unchallenging and due to the nature of this game that first 20 seconds of gameplay will be what you experience most as any mishap will transport you back to the beginning. I'm not advocating making the game easier as I appreciate a challenge but I don't appreciate being forced to repeat uninteresting gameplay several times over.  Many levels seem to be laden with challenges that can be fun at first but are repeated ad nauseum and end up feeling like a gimmick (for instance there will be a staircase in almost every level that requires consecutive jumps). These challenges quickly become tedius and only serve as a mechanism to return you once again to the boring part of the level. Levels can get quite long too so the chances you'll be repeating uninteresting gameplay is quite high. I've read comments about the game's soundtrack and the menu options do feature Anamanaguchi in the menu and credits the actual game's music is boring most of the time as it requires progress in the level to become interesting. I wonder why the game's music didn't feature Anamanaguchi as well. If you're looking for a game that's challenging and requires a high level of precision and quick reactions, although the format is different, other popular indie titles like Super Meat Boy and VVVVVV do a better job. Super Meat Boy's short levels and VVVVVV's room based format allow these games to respect the player's time. Score: 5/10

content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												Super Meat Boy is designed correctly. This is not. I saw someone compare this game to shoving pinecones up your own♥♥♥♥♥That's pretty accurate.The main problem with this game is that the game throws a lot of stuff at you that you can't predict beforehand, at which point you will die, because you aren't given enough time to react. Then you will be sent to the start of the level, and play through the level (a minute or two) until you get to the same place. If you guessed correctly as to how to beat what just killed you, you get to be killed by the next thing. Just try and beat the last two stages of World 1-- Marathon, and the boss. It's pretty damn frustrating.Typical level progress:<- n ->[..........] ^[--.......] |[----....] n/c[-----...] |[-------]V=> time to beat level is O(n^2) because screw you that's whySo why is Super Meat Boy properly designed, when this isn't? Mostly because Super Meat Boy's levels are a lot shorter, and because you can see what's ahead before you throw yourself at it and die. Playing Bit.TRIP Runner is like playing a version of Guitar Hero where any missed note will fail you out of the song. Also, Bit.TRIP feels very rigid. It's a timing-based game where your movements form a song, except the resulting song normally isn't that good and your movements are rigid as hell.1/10 for effort

content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
												I genuinely wanted to like this game: it manages to make the unholy trinity of auto-scrolling/run, reaction times and collectibles into genuinely fun and compelling gameplay. I was thoroughly enjoying the game up until the last level of the first block of stages.There are no checkpoints in these levels, once you die you go all the way back to the start. While this presents no issue for the standard shorter levels, this becomes something of a hindrance in the aforementioned one. At first you may trip up on early obstacles which doesn't matter too much, but when you find yourself three-quarters of the way through a level and mis-time a button press for the tenth time you start to get frustrated and worn out. You eventually start making stupid mistakes earlier in the level and then give up.There are two schools of thought about this design choice:1) I, the writer, am awful at video games and should be removed from the public and placed in a retirement home so that the mean games can no longer make me feel like a useless idiot.2) Not having checkpoints is a♥♥♥♥♥♥move that artificially pads out the game time and gates it off to people who either don't possess the time, reactions or patience to endure this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.Based on your preference you should know whether this game is for you or not.

Posted: July 12, 2014
												Be prepared to develop an extreme love-hate relationship with BIT.TRIP RUNNER. It's an excellent side-scrolling platformer, but it's relentlessly unforgiving and hard as hell. Be warned upfront: there are no check points! In retrospect it works well and fits the game, check points would have made it too easy and casual - if that's what you're after then grab RUNNER 2.In many ways this game throws me back to the 80s in its simplicity, but it retains a modern gaming appeal and atmosphere that will keep you coming back for more and more... and more... and more. It's one of those 'just one more try' games. The modern take on 8 bit graphics is really good and brings the world to life. The music is great and never became repetitive like some people mentioned in their reviews. In fact, the music was one of the highlights of the game for me and always set the perfect mood.BIT.TRIP RUNNER occupies a pretty unique space when compared to typical platformers, and I can't think of any other game that competes with it head on. It's perfect for short, fun bursts of gaming and is guaranteed to test your platforming skills, no matter how seasoned you think you are. If you're in two minds about buying it, take the plunge. It's selling at the right price and well worth the money. If you can pick it up on special then it's an absolute no-brainer... even if it's not on special, I'd consider it a must buy and must play.

Posted: August 7, 2011
												BIT. TRIP RUNNER is a runner game: you take control of a character that is running and it's up to you to avoid obstacles by kicking them, by sliding under them, by jumping over them, etc.. If you don't, you'll begin the run again and loose every gold or bonus obtained. If you can do a 100%, you can play a retro-challenge level.However, you have to make sure that the mapping of the keys is suiting you, else, you'll make many mistakes. Besides, you need to be coordinated: you jump but you need to immediately slide, in other words, some parts are really tricky. And if you miss a jump and touch a stair, you're sent back to the beginning as I don't recall any checkpoint.Anyway, the challenge is real, as at one point, I couldn't pass 1-4. I did it since but the difficulty is sometimes too much for me, so, I had to abandon the idea to finish it and to unlock more achievements.The graphics are those of retro-gaming: with pixels. And it's not desserving the game. The soundtrack is also an excellent point. It's very well suited.Anyway, BIT. Posted: July 12, 2014
												Be prepared to develop an extreme love-hate relationship with BIT.TRIP RUNNER. It's an excellent side-scrolling platformer, but it's relentlessly unforgiving and hard as hell. Be warned upfront: there are no check points! In retrospect it works well and fits the game, check points would have made it too easy and casual - if that's what you're after then grab RUNNER 2.In many ways this game throws me back to the 80s in its simplicity, but it retains a modern gaming appeal and atmosphere that will keep you coming back for more and more... and more... and more. It's one of those 'just one more try' games. The modern take on 8 bit graphics is really good and brings the world to life. The music is great and never became repetitive like some people mentioned in their reviews. In fact, the music was one of the highlights of the game for me and always set the perfect mood.BIT.TRIP RUNNER occupies a pretty unique space when compared to typical platformers, and I can't think of any other game that competes with it head on. It's perfect for short, fun bursts of gaming and is guaranteed to test your platforming skills, no matter how seasoned you think you are. If you're in two minds about buying it, take the plunge. It's selling at the right price and well worth the money. If you can pick it up on special then it's an absolute no-brainer... even if it's not on special, I'd consider it a must buy and must play.

Posted: August 7, 2011
												BIT. TRIP RUNNER is a runner game: you take control of a character that is running and it's up to you to avoid obstacles by kicking them, by sliding under them, by jumping over them, etc.. If you don't, you'll begin the run again and loose every gold or bonus obtained. If you can do a 100%, you can play a retro-challenge level.However, you have to make sure that the mapping of the keys is suiting you, else, you'll make many mistakes. Besides, you need to be coordinated: you jump but you need to immediately slide, in other words, some parts are really tricky. And if you miss a jump and touch a stair, you're sent back to the beginning as I don't recall any checkpoint.Anyway, the challenge is real, as at one point, I couldn't pass 1-4. I did it since but the difficulty is sometimes too much for me, so, I had to abandon the idea to finish it and to unlock more achievements.The graphics are those of retro-gaming: with pixels. And it's not desserving the game. The soundtrack is also an excellent point. It's very well suited.Anyway, BIT. TRIP RUNNER is a good little game, well-done and that is worthy of at least being tried.

Posted: December 28, 2013
												BIT.TRIP RUNNER is an interesting retro-looking, rhythm & platforming game. The game starts out simple enough, the first few levels only requiring one to use the jump button, adding a kick, duck/slide and block (certain projectiles only) later on.There are 3 difficulties to choose from, Easy, Normal & Perfect. Unfortunately, Normal was testing my patience before I was halfway thru the first zone. The reason being: there are no checkpoints during the levels. None. Sometimes this isn't that big of a deal, but when attempting the last couple of levels in a zone it's incredibly annoying because these levels are way longer than the others.Upon completion of a level perfectly (by grabbing all the gold & the plus shaped power-ups), a bonus level awaits with graphics like that of the Atari classic, Pitfall. In these bonus levels one hit and it's over. There's no restarting at the beginning. You will have to complete the level perfect again to try the bonus level and aim for a perfect on it.RUNNER consists of three zones of 11 levels (and a bonus level for each one) plus a boss level, which could have you spending quite a bit of time trying to get perfects on everything. Recommended, but be warned that the lack of checkpoints and the frustrating difficulty might not be for everyone.

Posted: June 8, 2014
BIT.TRIP RUNNERA throwback to the 8bit era of fiendishly tricky platform games, reminiscent of games like Jumping Jack on the ZX Spectrum.Rating 5/10The first thing you'll learn about BIT.TRIP RUNNER is that it's a game that requires perfect timing and precision as well having to memorise level layouts and obstacles as there are no checkpoints and that each level has to be completed in a single run as failure returns you to the beginning of the level.This requirement of a perfect run is both what makes and breaks Bit.Trip Runner. At its best it's a gloriously fluid experience as you meticulously learn the obstacles on a level and the feeling of exhilaration when you manage to pull of a perfect run. However it's also at times an incredibly frustrating experience. There are a handful of levels that are too long which can lead to extended attempts to the point of quitting and some obstacles require such pin-point precision that means failure towards the end of the level is a maddening experience as you watch your character revert back to the start. However if you stick with it your perseverance is rewarded.There is much to recommend in Bit.Trip runner, from the visuals, music and the challenge but I would only recommend it to those who like an old fashioned challenge, for those who like their games to be unforgiving and to reward patience and practise as well as precision.

Posted: January 20, 2012
												You run at blazing speeds through sidescrolling levels jumping over, sliding under and kicking obstacles while collecting gold and multipliers.  Everyone gets the same score on the level by collecting all the gold, then there's a bonus level afterward which is the place you earn your spot on the leaderboards by collecting more gold than others have.  Meaning if you want to try at a higher score you have to redo the entire level just to play the bonus level again, which is a surprisingly stupid mechanic.  Game's alright for a brief romp and does take some skill and reflex, but ultimately it's just that -- alright.  People who love the indie retro graphics/tunes scene will squee.

Posted: July 9, 2014
												Commander Video runs from left to right and you have to help him jump, slide and kick his way thru various obstacles. Every time you jump, Slide or whatever past an obstacle a little musical note is played, Power-ups fill out the background music. So during the best parts of the game a little jaunty tune is played as your kicking, sliding and jumping. Collect all the gold on a level to get a bonus retro challenge level. So the game seems to come down to memorization and synchronized button mashing. Once you get to a tricky part and miss something you have to start the level over again. I needed to replay a level many times before getting the timing or whatnot to a tricky part down. And then the next tricky part after it comes along. Needless to say I would eventually make it thru the level. But with only 3 or 4 more levels to go, I just don't care anymore. Now maybe in the bad old days when all you had were a handful of games to play at any one time I would have finished this game. Today I have over 60 games I haven't played yet, So it's time to move on.Edit - It's an OK game, Marginal thumbs up.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												GAME: BIT.TRIP RUNNERBUYING PRICE: N/A (GIFTED)RATING: 8/10This action platformer was quite better than originally expected, if I bought the game at its current price rather than getting it as a free gift I think this game would have been worth it. Not much to say more than this game is quite difficult and requires a sense of rythm as a platformer with an appealing soundtrack. Difficult is enough to suffice playing over the same level multiple times to get the highest score but may seem relatively boring after a few levels due to the monotonous task one might be doing, however I always find myself coming back and progressing further. The art is simple and slick with interesting 3D background and ambient events to add to the experience. I recommend this game at its current price of £1.39.

Posted: January 27, 2014



YouTube™ Video: Steam Review E13 Bit.Trip Runner and Bit.Trip Runner 2: Future Legend of Rhythm Alien 

			Views: 99		

			BIT.TRIP RUNNER and BIT.TRIP RUNNER2: Future Legend of Rhythm Alien. Both games are fantastic indie arcade games. They are sweet and simple but very challenging and with great music to boot.		

BIT.TRIP RUNNER: A great little arcade game that is sure to challenge you in a variety of ways. BIT.TRIP RUNNER is a challenging game in it of itself and requires quick reflexes as well as patience. While it is simplistic the game offers a hidden layer of depth that is only marred by some basic design choices. Levels are fun…for a while, they become stale and repetitive since there is only ever one way to go and if you fail you must start over at the beginning of the level, so repeating the same sections over and over may not appeal to some and may frustrate even the most seasoned of gamers. Music and style are perfect for this game, it’s hard to imagine it looking nor sounding any different, the music has a great retro beat that suits the game well and the 16-bit retro style of the game gives it charm, as well as being creative and colorful which helps nail down the fast pace action it’s trying to drive.  Overall, BIT.TRIP RUNNER is a nice simple arcade game with fantastic music; it’s challenging and may seem unfair with overly long levels and may frustrate some gamers with having to repeat sections over and over. If you love a tough challenge, retro looking games or a game with great music for $10.00 USD it may be a bit much, however when on sale this game is easily worth it. You can also enjoy the game and support the developers by purchasing the awesome soundtrack that is also for sale. Either way BIT.TRIP RUNNER is certainly a game to consider adding to the collection of fun and challenging arcade games.-Thumbs Up from RoyialVideo Reviews can be found at: www.youtube.com/user/RoyialNetwork

Posted: January 12, 2014
												(Finished Wii version, re-boght on Steam.) BIT.TRIP RUNNER is an auto-runner. You have no control over Commander Video's movement speed, and your only interactions are jumping, ducking, kicking, and blocking objects that block your path.   The main difference between BIT.TRIP RUNNER and other auto-runners is that obstacles aren't randomly generated or placed in every stage, and instead appear in a set rhythm and melody to the music. As you collect gold bars and dodge obstacles, you fill in various bits of each stage's song, and the more power-up cores you find, the more intense the music gets and the higher your score will soar. The game is HIGHLY focused on immediate reaction, and if that's not your cup of tea, then your pattern memorization skills will be put to the ultimate test. RUNNER has a relatively smooth start to try and ease you into the experience, but if you're to complete the game then your execution is going to have to be near-flawless. There are no mid-stage checkpoints to save you, and one missed jump means being thrown back to the beginning of a stage to try again. It's easy to get caught up in a flurry of "just one more try"s, but that satisfaction isn't quite the same as you'd get from something like Super Meat Boy or Rogue Legacy. RUNNER can be rote almost to a fault, and it'll probably take people that enjoy very specific types of linear challenges to enjoy it. If there's one major issue with the game it's that there are some crazy intense swings and spikes in difficulty. Stage 1-11 - ODYSSEY will probably be enough to shut down most that aren't dedicated to trying to see the game to its end, and there are more than a few other bad apples in the bunch whose level of challenge can feel a bit excessive considering the game's lack of checkpointing. It's all doable with the right amount of practice, but again, if that kind of rote memorization isn't for you, it may be best to pass on this one. Otherwise, game on. It's a fantastic game with great music, a fun aesthetic, and engaging gameplay for those of us that like a little something different in rhythm games.

Posted: October 6, 2015
												Bit. Trip Runner is a simple but pretty fun game. Your task is basically to avoid obstacles by jumping, sliding, springing or blocking at just the right time in order to complete increasingly difficult levels. One mistake sets you back to the start of the level. This can get frustating especially towards the end with the last two levels in particular being very tough. I would say a bit similar to the likes of Cook Serve Delicious in that the gameplay consists only of accurate sequences of button presses but here timing is very important.

Posted: November 26, 2014
												I've never felt so frustrated by a game before that I felt inclined to uninstall it.This game is brutal in its timing, but it doesn't feel fair. The time windows for some jumps are very deceptive, and you're punished by being sent to the very beginning of the level every time for making very small mistakes. I expected a rythm based platformer, or something close to that, but it's almost impossible to follow along with any tempo. You basically just have to play over, and over again to memorize the level layout-- which isn't fun at all. I would say maybe, just maybe the game would have some redeeming factors if the music was any good, but it's pretty bland. Maybe I'm just really bad, but the game overall feels highly unrewarding. The level design feels unexciting, and beating levels feels like a chore.I would not recommend.

Posted: December 21, 2011
												A compilation of very bad gameplay choices to make an over challenging, over-punishing game that leaves the player with no sense of fun. Merely a challenge of how long you can stand the masochism till you give up and walk away. Cluttered graphics that make it hard to tell what buttons you're meant to be pressing, fast-based scrolling which means sometimes you can only win by remembering level layouts, little-to-no margin for error with the only punishment of sending you back the the start of what can be a very long level.There's also jittery frame-rates on even high-end systems to add to the difficulty adding to the final opinion that once again Gaijin Games proves that it can make pretty and nice sounding things, but it can't make fun games.

												Overly punishing platformer that requires route memorization over reflexes.  The later levels have some of the tightest (in a bad way) obstacle placements I've ever seen in a game. No actual "rhythm" to the game, either: the sounds are made as you hit the collectable objects or avoid obstacles, but there's no real rhythm to the way the obstacles are placed.  The music is OK, but you are hard pressed to enjoy it as you're probably gritting your teeth as you do the level the 95th time.  Avoid this for better platformers such as Super Meat Boy and Electronic Super Joy.

Posted: February 3, 2014
												I would give BIT. TRIP RUNNER a 5/10. BTR is a music and rhythm game, where you must perform a simple set of platforming moves to music. As you progress through the level, you can collect gold pieces or bonuses that allow each gold bar to be worth more. Each of these upgrades adds new levels of musical melody and harmony, making the music more complex and beautiful.Whenever your character that you control collects a gold piece, smashes through a box, or jumps over a cavern, the game reflects that by making a musical sound within the realm of the song. Your character, in essence, can add to the song, which is pretty cool. The music itself sounds great, an electronic, pulsing rhythm. You progress through 3 "worlds" each with a different setting, and each world has a dozen or so levels. Each world has similar style tunes, and each level within that world is slightly varied from the one before.As cool as the levels are though, I still don't recommend this game. The main thing that is frustrating is that you can make zero mistakes throughout the course of the level in order to beat it. While getting gold pieces does make the music sound better and gives higher scores you don't have to get it. But if you run into a block that can't be broken or miss jumping a gap, at all, through the whole level, for each level, you must start over at the beginning of that level.I am fine for having a difficult game, but some levels are quite hard and require precision, and sometimes the levels can have a lot going on to watch for. This can make it frustrating to practice the level a lot but see zero progress. Many of the later levels especially have a somewhat cheap mechanic at the end of the levels, that throw something random at you just as you feel you are near the end. Think you are done? Nope a random purple block with no leadup from the music or other channels after you are simply running on a flat path for 5 seconds takes you out and you start over, ending your perfect run.Because of that I can't recommend it. If you get it for a good price and are up for the challenge or like rhythm and music games, it may be worth a shot.

Posted: June 26, 2014
												If you like rhythm-based games, then DON'T BUY THIS GAME. Having been a fan of rhythm games that tie gameplay to music, I find this game almost unplayable. In fact, the only way I could play the game is with the music off. That's not to say the music in the game is bad.You see, the game is inherently flawed because instead of matching the game's sound output to the player's controller input, it matches it to the game objects. You don't jump to the music's beat, you have to jump slightly before it. This means you have to constantly fight against the music to jump, slide, and kick slightly BEFORE the beat, instead of with the beat. Considering the game's difficulty increases very early on, it's very difficult for me to play any more. If they had an offset function that allowed me to adjust the gameplay with the sound ala Stepmania, that would make this game playable.

Posted: November 28, 2011
												Providing a colorfol and musical romp that will likely entertain you for all of about half an hour, Bit.Trip Runner presents itself as a hybrid platformer-action-rhythm game, but it can be easily summed up as "Perform the required command at exactly the required moment to progress,"; there isn't any true freedom in deciding how to move through the levels beyond "jump here or die," and it quickly becomes an exercise in trial-and-error and mindless repetition. This title would have been better off with an autoplay feature so the programming could run through each level for you as a mildly entertaining 8-bit music video. There are multitudes of significanly more worthwhile rhythm-based games than this available, and I wholly recommend any one of those over Beat.Trip Runner.

Posted: April 20, 2014
												First review here:BIT.TRIP RUNNER is an interesting game, but that doesn't mean it's good. In fact, it is the opposite of good, it's a rage game. The only difference is that this rage game has the balls to charge you for this crap.One of the main selling points of this game is the music. Is it good? No, the music is annoyingly repetitive. Although I admit it does sound good for the first 2 levels of the game before you realise that it is practically the same thing over and over. Not only that, but there is no other sound at all. Just the sounds of jumping over rocks and trash cans. Also, there are these 'powerup' things that go from Hyper to Mega to Ultra to Extra, and they make the game sound more lively each time. Sounds cool right? Wrong. The music does get more lively until you get to Extra, which turns the music into low, slow sounds that break up your pacing and eventually leads to you losing the level. Speaking of levels...The level design, don't even get me started on the level design. First of all, no checkpoints? Really? I get that it is a kind of 'music' (if you could even call this music) game so you wouldn't want the 'song' to be broken up, but the game is so insanely difficult that it takes more than 30 minutes for a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ 2 minute level. Who thought this was a good idea? ALso, some of the powerups are in difficult to get places, which is good for a running game like this. The only problem is that some of these powerups are almost completely impossible to get. One powerup involves you jumping down a hole then springing back up. The problem here is that the spring throws you into a wall, which of course kills you instantly.So, the rating is probably what you want to see from this random guy on the internet.2/10 - Not recommended to all who wish to keep their sanity.

Posted: April 25, 2014
												Even though I can't recommend this game, I'm glad Gaijin Games listens to their players and addressed the issues that were in this game on their sequel, which is MUCH better, which were these things:Checkpoints, especially during bosses. Gave up after having to repeat fighting the first boss over and over.Better level design. (look at 1-11 Odyssey)Easy mode is actually easier. In this game easy mode just removes the gold you get. The obstacles are still there. Doesn't really make the game "easy" per se.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												I loved the sequel to this game, so naturally I thought I'd try the first and like it. Oh how wrong I was. I played the second on normal difficulty and of course had issues on some levels, but eventually I overcame them after a few tries. The level difficulty of normal in the first is vastly far from being the same as normal in the second. The 11th level of the 1st world (that's right, the first world) is so insanely difficult, I was about to switch difficulties to save my blood pressure. Then I learned that I'd have to re-do all the levels on easy. Like I'd do that to myself. Eventually, after at least 30+ tries I beat it (didn't get all the gold of course, I was lucky to even reach the finish). Next is the boss level, I thought it couldn't be too bad after the hell I'd just endured. Wrong again. This game is just too hard. It forces you to memorize rather than follow the rhythm. I'll have fun playing the second instead of torturing myself with the first.Oh by the way there are no checkpoints in the first game, go figure.

Posted: December 23, 2013
												This game is hard as ♥♥♥♥. You get an adrenaline rush like no other while being a good bit into a level realizing that one mistake will send you all the way back to the beginning. This could be a huge minus and for some 6 year olds, it is. However when you consider the fact that your character is forced to move at a certain pace whether you want to or not, you'll realize that the complete reset actually isn't that bad, as the play time of each level is already set, it all depends on how much you ♥♥♥♥ up. All positives aside though I would recommend that you eat this game in bites. Purely for health reasons. However the rush that this game gives makes it worth while playing every now and again, just to see if you can get a little further this time.

Posted: March 3, 2013
												Runner is the fourth and highlight game of the original Bit.Trip series by Gaijin, which is basically the Atari classic Pitfall! on steroids. You jump, slide, kick, spring and block to avoid obstacles, while grabbing gold and multiplier power-ups to attain the highest score possible. Overall, it is a musically-addictive and increasingly-intensive game to play frequently and minutes at a time.
