Posted: December 29, 2013
												This is a reflex based puzzle/game, where you are constantly moving to the right and dodging obstacles while hitting keys/buttons.  Be warned, the graphics flash often, and the constant movement on the screen may cause you to become dizzy from eye strain if an epileptic seizure (from the flashing) doesn't paralyze you first.If you are into masochism, as inflicted by video games, then this title is made for you.  Failure to avoid obstacles results in a total restart of a given level.Fun (for average people): 2/5Fun (for epileptic people): 0/5 (may result in death/seizure)Fun (for people who like Steam Trading Cards and/or Achievements): 5/5Fun (when you realize it only has 3 Card Drops and you can stop playing): 5/5

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2013
												BIT.TRIP RUNNER is a rhythm platformer. The input to this game is similar to that of rhythm games, but instead of colored buttons you have to press, you're given obstacles that you can either jump, slide under, kick or propel over, like a 2D platformer. Every successful action you make creates a sound or note, and the better you play the better the music becomes. The death system in this game is extremely cruel though, one mistake will send you back to the beginning of the level, and this can be really frustrating especially on the boss levels and on the long hard levels. They've "fixed" this on the sequel with optional checkpoints, but for those who want a challenge, this first game is the one to play.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20
												- Jump Jump Jump Duck Duck Jump Jump Jump Jump Jump Duck Jump Duck Duck Jump Jump Jump Uninstall LOL -The designers deliberately made the game very hard by the exclusion of checkpoints. You could call this "sadistic" or say it's meant to attract only the most diehard platformer fans (of which I am one), but it makes the game inaccessible and artificially extends the playtime. It's a crutch you see used a lot in indie platformers these days. Super Meat Boy was exceptionally hard but had an enormous amount of depth. Bit.Trip Runner is actually a pretty short and shallow experience if you add checkpoints. - Since this is a rhythmic platformer, a large part of the game experience is enjoying the music. But it's incredibly difficult to even get past the first world (of three total), and you don't really hear different music until then. By the time I got there I was so F***ing tired of the music in the first world I never want to play it again. Contrast that to Electronic Super Joy, 140, and Super Meat Boy, where I frequently go back and play levels just to hear the music.- This game is so bad that I'm deleting it from my library.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												I wish I could recommend this game. The idea is really cool especially for something that seems like it may be limited since it's a rail platformer. But there are problems... a lot of problems.Graphics: Look, I'm not going to complain about the graphics being 8bit. That's the style the game wanted to take itself (for the most part), and I'm ok with that. I actually like the basic look of the character and some of the 8bit objects in the world are pretty cool looking too. But then you have to realize that this is a game where the character never stops running. The background, the foreground, the obstacles you have to dodge... it just gets vomit inducing. It just looks so blurry that it hurts to look at this game for very long, and I'm somebody that doesn't get motion sickness very easy. If you get powerups, then the screen pretty much flashes every time you grab a gold piece. In a game where you have to have your eyes taped open to make sure you don't blink and miss a jump, having distractions like that is unforgivable.Gameplay: It's simple, and actually provides entertainment to an extent. At first, it's fun to get pass the slightly challenging obstacles. It feels nice to pass something that seems really difficult on your first try. The problem is this game is seriously one of the most repetitive games I've ever played in my life. I guess you could say a rail platformer that uses only a few buttons will inevitably be pretty repetitive, but they could've done much more with this game. If you play the game and come across a slightly challeging obstacle, you can be damn sure that you'll be doing that same exact obstacle twenty more times through the rest of the game (that's assuming you complete the rest of the game in a perfect run, which you won't)Replayability Value: As stated above, this game is repetitive. At first, it's repetitive because it's really easy, and not much can be done to change the repitition. Later on, it's repetitive because the level design lacks creativity and just rehashes the same things from the last few levels. After that, starting at about world 3-9, it's repetitive because you get killed by something that's actually a new challenge. Then you hit world 3-10 and it's repetitive because that new challenge is being milked for all its worth and is thrown into the next level 4 times and you get killed after completing it because you misjumped and hit the edge of a staircase. So, the replayability value is bad. Keep in mind, this is a game that forces you to start at the beggining of a level after one screw up. Yeah...Soundtrack: At first, I liked the soundtrack. It was interesting and kept me playing the game despite its lackluster gameplay. But just like the level design, they got lazy. The soundtrack sounds the same throughout the entire game. There may be slight changes, but it still sounds so bland after playing for a while. You get a headache from the ugly background, the repetitive music, and the fact that you have to keep playing the beggining of every level 200 hundred times because you can't get through these levels like a robot.Difficulty: Don't even get me started. Personally, this game bored the hell out of me until much later. I'll admit, 1-11 was hard because it was a couple of minutes long, and making a perfect run over a few minutes isn't easy, but I still got through it after several tries. Then the game got boring again. It got boring because the obstacles that I was coming across were the same obstacles I came across ten times in the last map. All of the sudden, I got to 3-9 and out of nowhere the game decided to throw, by far, the hardest obstacles the game has to offer. There was no warning, no slowly scaling diffculty leading up to this point, it just went haywire out of nowhere. But, luckily, it was at the very beggining of the round, so I had a good chance to practice and practice. Finally, I perfected it! Eventually I got pass the level, and even though it was difficult, I stayed positive and continued into the next level. I get through half of the level filled with obstacles I've seen before just to be greeted by this same ♥♥♥♥ing obstacle from 3-9. Then eventually I get to 3-11, and the same ♥♥♥♥ing obstacle once again. I played throughout this entire game and feel like I've only really played 4 different levels.And, don't get me wrong, I don't hate this game because I died a lot. I love Super Meat Boy and that game infuriates me to no end. The difference between this and SMB is that SMB had good level design. They implemented some obstacles you've seen before but they did it in new, clever ways. This game does no such thing. You just do what you did before.I wanted to like this game, but it has only provided me dissapointment and infuriation. Opinions are subjective, so take what you will from this review, but if I could do it all over again I wouldn't even get this game for free, it's just a waste of time that I've only put so many hours into because I'm obsessed with completing it.

You play a level by memorizing the jumps, dodges and punches, then you keep trying until you complete it just to experience the few moments of euforia before doing it all over again. number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2013
												BIT.TRIP RUNNER is quite simply a 'Simon Says' side-scrolling gauntlet, but instead of memorizing and pressing buttons to tones, you memorize buttons to obstacles in which your "Runner" evades or smashes. The game balances more toward frustration than reward. You must complete each gauntlet perfectly otherwise you start over at the beginning. They start out pretty short and easy, but then get much longer and much tougher. I got to a point where the frustration started compounding by making very simple mistakes trying to get to the part where I was stuck. It really needs a practice mode so that you can work on specifically hard spots. I find it much easier to forgo the agony and not play it. Take a pencil, stick it in your eyeball--you'll get the same sensation.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												It's way more frustrating than it's worth for me. The selling point for the game seems to be it's punishing difficulty, at least according to fan defenders on forums. Personally it's a game that I want to enjoy, with interesting visuals and music (the first time you see/hear them), and neoclassical gameplay style (there's really no classic game it's like, it's more similar to Guitar Hero than Mario or Sonic). Unfortunately, every time you miss a step, you get to repeat the entire stage. The music and visuals run very thin, very quickly. The reward for beating an insanely difficult for no apparent reason level is that you've just beaten an insanely difficult for no reason level and can move on to the next one. I've never had this much trouble jumping up a flight of stairs in my life. 2/5

												BIT.TRIP RUNNER reminds me of an acid trip.So I was in Denver, tripping out and I sat down on a planter because I had just left a Ross's with pants one size too small. Me and my friend took a break while we waited for the girls to get back. They'd abandoned us to go to Forever 21 to get outfits for the rave we were going to. Anyways, We were sitting there and all of a sudden a bus passes about 6 inches away from us. My knees almost scrape the side of the bus and I'm staring into the windows of the bus only seeing my reflection and wondering "Why am I not reacting?"BIT.TRIP RUNNER is fast paced, chaotic and yet at the same time lulls you into a rythm. It grabs hold of your brain despite the bus that almost just took off your legs and says "Try again."

content:
Posted: July 15, 2013
												BIT.TRIP RUNNER is a quirky episode in the BIT.TRIP universe. As in every part of the series, you need to be very quick with your actions. You run towards your goal and try to evade obstacles. Sounds easy, but it will get pretty difficult the farther you progress. Very cool chiptune soundtrack paired with retro-style visuals – a frustratingly beautiful journey!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 10, 2013
												Bit.Trip.Runner is one of those games you'll come back to quite frequently for a quick run through just to enjoy the music and basic gameplay.Gameplay mechanics are standard and timing is everything, but not too intimidating. You'll quickly learn the progressive controls and be hopping, sliding, and kicking with ease. The challenge with the game comes with having to be 100% accurate. One mis-step of timing failure and it's back to the start of the level. Some may say this isn't a big deal, but the levels get quite long and so you quickly realize the smallest flaw killed you mere feet from the finish line.The soundtrack is what truly makes this game standout though. Music is of course a subjective thing, but the gameplay mixed with the semi-chiptune soundtrack made this an engaging experience.

number of helpful: 8 of 16 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2013
												BIT.TRIP RUNNER is a one-trick pony, like many indie games. It's a platformer with a neat 8-bit techno soundtrack. Your character runs at a fixed speed, and has to avoid obstacles by jumping, sliding, and kicking. The moves you make are timed to the beat of the soundtrack. That's kind of neat. However, when you miss a jump, slide, or kick, you have to go back to the beginning of the level. That part is not so neat, it's super-annoying.It may not be fair, but it's hard not to compare this game to other recent super-difficult retro indie platformers, like VVVVVV and Super Meat Boy. BIT.TRIP RUNNER is a lesser game than those. It's just not very fun.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												For some reason, I keep playing this game even if I really suck at it. You play a level by memorizing the jumps, dodges and punches, then you keep trying until you complete it just to experience the few moments of euforia before doing it all over again. The design is clever enough to have loading between dying and trying again, making it easy and (relatively) painless to keep trying. The music changes and intensifies as you pick up some items, giving you both visual and auditorial rewards.I recommend playing with a controller instead of mouse+keyboard.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												This game is annoying and addictive. Bit.Trip Runner is one of those indie games which I looked at and didn't expect all that much from, I was unsure how any of it worked but I only expected a normal indie game with little to it. Of course I was wrong. The graphics are surprisingly good despite the almost retro look and feel, the music actually had an effect on me, even if it was just me humming along. There isn't much story to it, but the game really doesn't need one. the controls are confusing and fast, but introduced slowly so you pick them up easily enough.Positives-Fun and Addictive-Brilliant soundtrack-Good visuals despite indie feel-ChallengingNegatives-Frustrating-A little short if you have good rhythmIt has got to be one of the more fun games like this I have played. The music was one of the best bits for me, but the game itself is impressive. I'd suggest this game for anyone liking a little bit of challenge and with good rhythm.

Posted: November 25, 2013
												Calling it a runner would do this game a huge disservice. Bit.Trip Runner has some of the best music in video games and while it can be easy to finish the levels, to master them can be nearly impossible. The visuals are striking without taking away from the objectives of the level. Runner is a fantastic game and it doesn't hurt that it's often on sale for about 2.00

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												BIT.TRIP RUNNER reminds me of an acid trip.So I was in Denver, tripping out and I sat down on a planter because I had just left a Ross's with pants one size too small. Me and my friend took a break while we waited for the girls to get back. They'd abandoned us to go to Forever 21 to get outfits for the rave we were going to. Anyways, We were sitting there and all of a sudden a bus passes about 6 inches away from us. My knees almost scrape the side of the bus and I'm staring into the windows of the bus only seeing my reflection and wondering "Why am I not reacting?"BIT.TRIP RUNNER is fast paced, chaotic and yet at the same time lulls you into a rythm. It grabs hold of your brain despite the bus that almost just took off your legs and says "Try again."

content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												It's way more frustrating than it's worth for me. The selling point for the game seems to be it's punishing difficulty, at least according to fan defenders on forums. Personally it's a game that I want to enjoy, with interesting visuals and music (the first time you see/hear them), and neoclassical gameplay style (there's really no classic game it's like, it's more similar to Guitar Hero than Mario or Sonic). Unfortunately, every time you miss a step, you get to repeat the entire stage. The music and visuals run very thin, very quickly. The reward for beating an insanely difficult for no apparent reason level is that you've just beaten an insanely difficult for no reason level and can move on to the next one. I've never had this much trouble jumping up a flight of stairs in my life. 2/5

												Although purposefully blocky and a tad repetitive, this game is not bad so much as spitefully difficult. Players beware.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												I really, really disliked this game. BIT.TRIP RUNNER takes the mechanics of The Impossible Game and cranks it up to 11. However, whereas The Impossible Game was simplistic, BTR is punishing and convoluted.You have a few different commands mapped to different keys (or buttons if you're on a controller) such as ducking, jumping, kicking, etc. Depending on the upcoming obstacle, you have to do one of those. However, the game is sorta 2.5D, and there's a very annoying effect in some instances (especially concerning stairs) where the camera will move enough for you to lose a bit of accuracy in your timing.Like The Impossible Game, interacting with something will send you to the beginning of the stage. Thank goodness the stages are much shorter, because after crashing into the same exact wall 10 times, I don't think I could have dealt with the level going on for much longer of a distance than that.The pickups in the level are pointless. After getting them all, you get a rainbow behind your character, but it doesn't seem to do anything at all. Otherwise, they just add points, but they're so easy to get that everyone must have the same score on every level that doesn't include other methods of getting points.Overall, I had a terrible time with this game, and I would rather wait for The Impossible Game to get off of Greenlight than recommend this to a friend.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												After playing the second installment in the Runner series and loving it to bits, I was enticed to buy the original, and am very sorry to say that this game does not hold up. I'll refrain from comparing this game to the sequel as much as possible during this review in order to keep things fair.To start off. This game looks bad and sounds boring. I can't comprehend as to why the developer would want to keep commander video as a 2D pixelart sprite, and have the rest of the world in a disgusting looking, 3D, roblox-esque style. It would be much better if it were all just pixelart. To make matters worse, the music,  which is supposed to be one of the game's main features, just doesn't mix well. The best description I can give it is that is sounds flat. The little chimes that play as you surpass every obstacle make it sound like a toddler bashing his xylophone at random, unfitting moments. There are upgrades you collect in each level which increase your mutliplier, and make the music climax, but that's the only redeeming factor about this bad soundtrack. Particularly, during the first boss battle, I was stuck listening to the same loop over and over and over again, for about 20 minutes. This made the battle downright boring.Whilst I'm discussing the boss battle, I need to bring up something that's downright shamefull about this game: The fact that it breaks the golden rule of good video game etiquette. That rule being "When a player reaches a lose state, it should be his fault and not the game's". During the entire game, you spend your time looking to the right of the screen, watching out for obstacles. The fact that these obstacles move from the right side to the left means you have enough time to react and avoid those obstacles. This boss battle broke that mechanic, and sent obstacles towards me from just a couple of pixels infront of my character. The game stopped being something that could be compared to "The Impossible Game" and more like "I Wanna Be The Guy", where winning was no longer about how skilled you are, but about how you can remember exactly when you need to perform a precise action.I suggest you purchase the sequel, and forget this game even exists.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												Bit.Trip Runner was designed by someone who likes listening to music and jumping in videogames, but unfortunately they just decided to smash the two together and call it a day without htinking about the implications. The music in Bit.Trip Runner is synchronized with the game, so when your character jumps over an obstacle, a note plays, but the note plays when you clear the obstacle, not when you start the jump, so if you're musically inclined and start to jump with the rhythm of the music, you'll always jump too late and have to start over at the beginning of the level. Basically, if you can carry a tune, you're boned, because the instant you try to become one with the beat, you lose.

												You won't stop running with music, because...yeah, jump, jump, on rocks and then collect gold, yeah! That's what i feel!Thanks to Ridian for finding me and for gifting me that awesome of one of the BIT.TRIP series.Story: 7/10 - It's so intensive, but the story is minimal and it is more a rhythm game.Controls: 10/10 - I can tell, you need some skill to avoid and bash some things on rhythm games, if you're a child you won't be getting this easily.Graphics: 9/10 - Both 2d and 3d graphics are a good mix.Music: 10/10 - Both 8bit and then modern-generation music are also a good mix.Gameplay: 10/10 - The gameplay is perfect for a rhythm game, both a jump n run game and a rhythm game is a very nice mix!Total: 4.6/5

content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												BIT.TRIP RUNNER is trolling at its finest. I went back to play this several years after giving up on the 100% in order to get the trading cards, and wow, just wow. Whoever created "The Guantlet" (a level late in the game, and notorious by this point) must have been wracked with fits of maniacal laughter as they developed the game. That level is a slap in the face to decency, and trollbait for rage-quitters. A close runner up to "Guantelet" is the hilarity of "Odyssey." I won't spoil it for you, but you'll get the joke when you understand that level. And you'll know the joke's on you. Be warned: you may want to destroy the equipment you're using to play this game, and yet you won't because then you would have to stop. And it's just. too. addictive. to stop.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2014
												Ehh. Still mixed thoughts on this one. I was a little harsh on it before but some of the criticisms do still hold valid. The lack of checkpoints goes directly against the concept of allowing the player to learn levels and as a result makes the game very tedious. I'm sure this was intentional but it's certainly not good design. This is mostly an issue on the longer levels though, on the shorter levels the game is a fun level of challenging without being frustratingly so. Suffers a bit from a lack of variety though, there's really not a huge variety of level design. The music's decent, the graphics are fine for the style. It's... alright. Competent. Passable.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2015
												The auto-runner genre is one that’s filled with all sorted of titles so to really stand out you’ve got to create something specialBIT.TRIP RUNNER is a rhythm / music platformer with a fully character-based adventure that’s the latest chapter in the award-winning critically acclaimed BIT.TRIP series.Run, jump, slide, and kick!GameplayAnother fun well paced game that’s only challenge is you get into the rhythm of the level! As with many auto-runners, the pace picks up as you progress and the challenges become more complex.CameosWhat’s rather nice about this game is the cameos from other Indie Game characters such as Super Meat Boy, these pop up in all sorts of places so you’ll have to keep your eyes glued if you wish to spot them all!SoundtrackSometimes we don’t often talk about when highlighting features of a game is the soundtrack and really it’s one of the most important parts of a game. It keeps you immersed, add to the emotion of the game and even makes you jump from time to time. BIT.TRIP RUNNER has one of the best soundtracks from the Indie Game Genre it’s simply perfect for the gameplay.VisualsA rainbow of colour delivered in well crafted blocks, whilst side-loaded it still creates enough depth that the story can interact with the landscapes in ways that help to make this game feel very modern even when it reflects a retro feel.RetroSpeaking of retro, one of our favourite features about this game is if you perfectly finish a level you get to go on a bonus retro adventure, it’s like having two games in one!The challengeWith more than 50 levels, new easy and hard modes plus leaderboards and achievements you will find yourself not only challenge your friends but yourself in your quest to be on top with the perfect score!Published Blog Post[www.dabs.com]

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												It's the Boku No Pico of videogames.How? That's rather difficult to explain. As a platformer it's frustrating, unfair, the controls are loose, the music is repetitive, level design is grating...but despite its numerous faults if you let it the game will suck you in for hours on end. No matter how it might enrage the player, it is *very* difficult to stop playing. To say a game is that compelling sure sounds like a great compliment, but I assure you it's not. Anger sets in after the first few minutes and builds--not declines--with each successive level. It's a Simon Says at a million miles an hour, forcing the player to perform a series of monotonous tasks to a degree of precision in the milliseconds, and there's not a moment's respite for failure. Expect to see the beginning of each level many times. While the challenge and satisfaction of success could make the game very rewarding for the few willing to take the time to master its nuance, it's plagued by control issues. Suffice to say, the input feels unacceptably loose and many times the player can expect to have quite a defeats snatched from the jaws of victory by a missed keypress or delay of only a few frames. This I cannot overstate: the game expects the player to perform to a level that it itself cannot reach. So why persist? It's succubus! The level isn't *that* hard. You can't be *that* bad at such a simple game. You were *so* close that last attempt. Surely you'll get it *this* time. It's just enough to keep playing, but not enough to feel any satisfaction for a victory.Maybe I'm nitpicking, but I can't bring myself to recommend a game that demands so much from the player, but isn't precise enough to handle the players it's trying to court. With a little refinement and some tighter controls, I could see this as a great Super Hexagon or Audiosurf-alike, but that's simply not the case.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2014
												BIT.TRIP RUNNER is a REALLY hard game, and it can get repetitive. But some games are all about that and learning how to move through a stage until it's in your bones. You'll be mostly jumping over, sliding under and kicking through obstacles in every stage. Boss fights are essentially the same as any other stage, but they still have a different vibe about them.The music is not only nice and catchy, but it actually helps you a little bit, since a note will play everytime you avoid an obstacle. You'll get used to the music, remember it and it'll help you remember the obstacles ahead. The music also get more intense as you get the boosters along the way.Graphics are nice retro style 2.5D with lots of colors and rainbows and it gets close to psychodelia sometimes. It can get a bit too confusing to me, but I guess it's due to my poor video card. =/All in all, it's a good game, though not an outstanding one. Just make sure you're looking for a real challenge before purchasing it!

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												This has bad design all over it.Your character always runs right and you have to jump at the right time to avoid obstacles. This is a simple game, but it works against you in a way that is just dependent on your abilities as a gamer.I won't say that the game sucks because you don't know what's coming ahead of you and it's all about memorization. Some people won't like that, I'm not the biggest fan, but I play retro games made that way and manage to find them fun if they feature good design otherwise (good controls, level design, enemy behavior, etc.).The game sucks because while the camera is often placed fine, there are very important moments when the action gets fast and you have to make a sudden fall to avoid an obstacle at the top, at those moments the camera stays in place and doesn't give you the focus necessary on the bottom part. (One might not know what I'm talking about if they didn't play later levels.)And you'll notice a ton of moments when the game is slightly buggy or the controls suddenly don't respond in an optimal way. I wonder how I got through the game at all.I heard Runner2 is an improvement in many ways, in fact a great game. The first game though, it's frustrating for all the wrong reasons and that's coming for a retro gaming fan like me.

												Overall the game is fun and rewarding to play. Although there are some levels that will make you want to pull your hair out, finally getting the "perfect" rating on a level that you've been stuck on for a while is a great feeling.However, towards the end of the game the difficulty level ramps up to the point of unfairness. This makes the ability to get a perfect on a level almost impossible unless you win the coin flips or play it numerous times to figure out exactly when to jump and when not to jump. content:
Posted: May 19, 2014
												Ohhh BIT TRIP !! This is in my opinion the best in the BIT-TRIP series,other BT games are based around different styles of gameplay and this one is all about running without dying,it's fast paced and will have you shouting at the screen of unfair pixels grrrr anyway I enjoy runner style games like that of the warioware series and others,this however is the best and is very challenging,my only complaint is that I would sometimes like to speed up and slow down the gameplay at the cost of a time bar or something like that,a good idea for BIT-TRIP 3 !I play this game every other day and find myself coming back for more even when the challenge can be really tough at times and I feel like smashing the screen in,I take a break and come back to it so it must be good ! The game also sounds great however there is no audio timing to gameplay sync like you are led to believe from other reviews but it's still a fun run.There are plenty of hidden goodies including many steam awards for playing and that keeps me going when I get a bit angry with the brutal difficulty that some of the levels display,I am on world 2,the first boss was a nightmare and the pace seems to have calmed down to introduce new play mechanics,I might also add that world 2 is quite refreshing to look at after being stuck on world one for so long.I will also note that I am playing the game on normal difficulty,I didn't know it could be set to easy and I would recommend others to keep it on normal,my 6 year old also plays this game and he can also complete quite a few of the stages and like me,he is also addicted to the daily BIT-TRIP play through challenge.Great game that all old school arcade lovers should play,if you like a solid challenge that is also fun and rewarding then get this game and have some fun but be prepared to also shout at it grrr8/10 !!

content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
												Interesting art style, nice soundtrack and great game play = one of the better games I have played all-time.  It is a game that challenges your reflexes, memory and can frustrate you to where you want to rage quit but you don't stop playing because it is just so much fun.  I will say though if you get into a situation where you find you are not making any progress sometimes well just quit the game and come back to it another day.  I was able to learn to realize for me at least that quite often my best attempt at clearing something will come in my first 5 or so attempts in a session.  Now that is not to say you can't play it longer and have fun and clear stuff as I have done that too but I am just saying some days you will need to step away from it so that you get the most enjoyment out of playing the game.  Why wait til you rage quit?  Just quit when it is obvious you are getting nowhere.Anyway .. bottom line ..10/10 and like I said earlier one of the greatest games of all-time

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5
												A supremely grueling exercise in patience, memory, and repetition.After playing off-and-on for three years, I've finally beaten BIT.TRIP RUNNER.  While I feel a sweet sense of fulfillment and satisfaction, the punishing difficulty borders on insane.  With no checkpoints or second chances, perfection is demanded for complex stages that can last for ages.  Worse, the visuals sometimes hinder the player's accuracy from lack of clarity.  You'll find yourself hitting brick walls hard, only to punch through them from playing a level over and over for dozens of times.  However, the eminently charming graphics and dynamic soundtrack will keep you motivated to come back.If you can endure the challenge, you'll find an extremely artistic and challenging experience that you can't put down - and that's just the base game.  For even greater masochists, there are higher difficulty modes - including Perfect mode - with collectable gold and additional after-levels.  With all this value, a recommendation is easy, if not highly pained.

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 2, 2013
												Despite my eternal hatred towards this game's graphic, I'll try to write... objectively. I hope.Gameplay: similar to Super Meat Boy. Frustrating and requires you to practice so you can get through a level. I was stuck like 30 minutes trying to beat 1-4 level, of which I nearly threw the towel in and uninstalled the game.You control an ugly character that can run forward. At first you can only make him jump, but as you progress deeper he can slide and kick. How he can keep on sliding and kicking endlessly while running is beyond my logic though. Unlike SMB, your char runs forward automatically, so you just need to concentrate on kicking jumping and sliding to avoid the walls / obstacles.Level designs can be incredibly tedious, as you keep on repeating moves you do in the first one-third of the level and repeat and repeat it. However, because of that, learning curve isn't that steep. As you memorize the first one-third, the rest is pretty easy.Game has NO checkpoint. If you die one second before you reach the finish line, you will repeat the entire level. No question asked. Imagine if it happened to you? I felt it many times, don't worry, I know the feeling.Graphic: no further comment or I'll look like a complete hater. I even have problem reading the menus.Sound: Okay, I guess. I am not a fan but I don't dislike it either. Pretty fitting for the game.Replayability: Based on levels I've finished, it's close to zero. Unless you want to fix your score, then there's no reason to play previous levels.And lastly, as far as I'm aware of, no proper controller support for Dinput gamepads. Even when I try to attach x360ce the game doesn't recognize it. I don't know which one is wrong - as that emulator can hook my controller perfectly for many games.Buy it or not? I personally would just think this game is a bundle material. And certainly for 10 bucks it is too expensive. Maybe a hardcore fan of Bit Trip games is alright I guess.

content:
Posted: January 18
												This game is addicting. Luckily, it is fairly short. You definitely need high-tier reaction skills. The aesthetic it portrays is also very nice, but let's not get out of hand here for innovation. This title's graphics are stripped STRAIGHT from Katamari Damacy, a truly innovative title that will go down as one of the very best. Even with the obvious inspiration, this game succeeds in the runner genre with its total package. To me it's just a fun and challenging game with a pick up and play attitude that doesn't leave me obsessed with getting everything.Expect to die a lot as you learn the levels. The biggest pain is repeating instances of platforming that are super easy only to come to the tough parts a minute into the level. As others have mentioned this may not be your cup of tea, but it does feel very good to complete levels like The Odyssey at 1-11. The difficulty curve is definitely a little bit all over the place, and there are only three zones to play. Plenty of levels mind you, just expect certain levels to ♥♥♥♥ you off more than others.Again, don't play this if you don't want a decent challenge and some repetition. The music is pretty good for a simple game like this, though a bit repetitive as is the game in many parts. Overall, this is still a solid recommendation for platform lovers that want a challenge.I play this at 4K resolution through custom resolution toggle/hack in Nvidia CP with SMAA injected. It seems to do 4K this way even if you don't have the in-game resolution toggled correctly. There were no jaggies basically. Looks perfect. Nvidia DSR did not work nor did staying on 1080p desktop and toggling resolution in game. So use a custom resolution if you want true 4K.With a DS4 controller through Input Mapper lag does not seem too bad. Give it a try, but you have been warned. Vsync may add a bit of lag as well but I passed some of the hardest stages without too much trouble.

content:
Posted: November 20, 2014
												BIT.TRIP RUNNER is a frustrating, repetitive title. After playing a few hours, you wouldn't be blamed for uninstalling it. Instead of focusing on skill, RUNNER leans more towards 'memorization'. You play a random pitch black thing with a white spot for eyes, as well as arms and legs. Really good character design there, instead of making an interesting character, just throw random stuff into it.Wow...Your character decides to run to the right, without stopping. It is up to you to control his jumping, sliding, kicking, and shield. But instead of taking skill, BIT.TRIP RUNNER decides "NO! Memorization is more fun". You die if you touch one thing, and you go back to the beginning of the level.No checkpoints...Let that sink in....NO CHECKPOINTS...I hate this game so much, but luckly, the sequel is far better! Play the sequel, but don't play this.-MandatoryAlcatraz

Posted: July 3, 2013
												Hello everyone Elemix here again with another game review, this time I'll be looking at Bit.Trip Runner a 'indie' game. Here's a little back story of the game. You play as a stickman from the popular Newground flashes and you have to rescue your girl friend from the main bad game (like that's never done before, Bethesda). Now In the past I've never really had any good experience with indie-games but maybe this one will be better. Lets dive into Bit. Trip Runner!When you first start up the game you start off running and you have no control of your character. I mean no control what so ever, if you try going left doesn't work and if you try jumping it doesn't work. At first I assumed my keyboard was broken but I tried my other keyboard AND I HAD THE SAME PROBLEM. Seriously in this game the controls are just not existed.Graphics look like tehy're staight up indie doo doo, the guy looks like my fat over weight friend mettic.All and all Bit.Trip runner will make you run from it seeing how terrible it is.

												this game will make you suffer but let it be known that i love experiencing intense suffering every once in a while. once you reach a certain level of enlightenment and let go of your anger its pretty fun, but until then youre experiencing existential horror of the likes youve never known because seriously? some of these levels are literally impossible to get on your first run? half the time was spent with me going, 'how the heck did i not see this coming?' well, for starters, while the visuals are quite pretty and colorful and horribly distracting, it may have just been my impaired eyesight (low contrast is the worst and focus is hard to keep), but sometimes it was hard to see objects in the foreground against the background. may have had something to do with the 2D on 3D (which, while unique and charming, again made it hard to see), or maybe my attention span didnt run long enough. in either case, it cost me an entire run, and also my dearly bought patience.that said i love this game and would definitely recommend it, if only to watch other people wailing in agony as well.

Posted: December 26, 2011
												BIT.TRIP RUNNER is an oddity, particularly because it's a Wii port and that's a bit on the strange side to begin with. There are three levels divided up into eleven stages and a 'boss' stage, in between each stage is a challenge stage where the real high score hunting comes in as it's relatively easy to unlock each one through normal play, as the path the game takes puts the gold blocks required right in your way.As a game, it's relatively simple. You automatically run forward and have to duck, kick, block and jump through a stage full of obstacles. This sounds very shallow in depth, but the patterns introduced can be a bit of a shock to encounter at first, but are satisfying once conquered. The game is all too aware of how long you hold the jump button. This belongs among games such as Super Meat Boy and Jamestown - Difficult without being punishing, but satisfying when finally beaten

Posted: July 24, 2013
												I like the style of this game, and I'm not opposed to these types of runners, but it is way too punishing.  Some kind of checkpoint system or gold-loss or something when you get hit seems necessary (maybe three hits, but getting hit means no bonus, or maybe it pushes you back only a certain amount but you lose all gold before that point)  Some levels are too long to justify playing through again and again.I'd say that in general, I wouldn't recommend this now that Runner2 exists, as it does almost everything better.  However, I don't want to totally shy you away from it - there's some good stuff here and if you're a bit.trip fan and completionist, go for it.  It's not bad, just make sure to play this BEFORE Runner2 and you won't be disappointed.

												BIT.TRIP RUNNER is a game where you must press buttons in order to jump over and slide under obstacles, kick the said obstacles or block (only 3rd world) orange bullets. Your character runs automatically. The games has a really nice art style and good soundtrack. If you hit any obstacle in the level, you have to restart the whole level and some of the levels are pretty hard. The game is fun UNTIL you get to the last 3 stages (3-10, 3-11 and "boss"). I can assuredly say that I spent at least half of the time I played this game on these stages. The reason is that these stages are utter ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. You have to make some of the hardest jumps not just once and for me, those last 3 stages made me so frustrated that I would recommed buying this, but only playing until and completing 3-9, the last 3 stages are not worth it, they are completely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ized and will make you furious.

Posted: March 2, 2014
												Aka: OH GOD WHY DO I GET SO ANGRY WHEN I FAIL?Bit.Trip Runner is the third in the Bit.Trip series, which makes a break from convention of the previous two. This time, you actually play as Commander Video in a side-scrolling platformer. The screen moves at a cracking pace while you run constantly in a 3D retro 8-bit inspired world. Your basic functions are to jump, slide, and kick your way around/through obstacles, while collecting gold and powerups, to reach the finish line at each stage.While this seems simple enough, and it is easy early on, it quickly delves into devious territory, requiring the utmost attention and rhythm. As with the previous Bit.Trip titles, the gameplay is heavily dependent on the music. As you collect powerups, the music becomes more and more intense, so you know after a few of them (and when that glorious rainbow trails behind you), you’re close to the end. It’s often much easier to time your jumps with the music, rather than looking at when obstacles are coming up.But if you fail; fall down a gap, hit a wall, etc, it immediately carries you all the way back to the beginning, and starts straight away in that dull pre-powerup music. It’s incredibly demoralising, to know that you were so close, only to go right back to the start music. Particularly on the longer levels (damn you, Odyssey).Because of the instant reload times, much like Super Meat Boy (who also gets a sneaky cameo), it forces you to keep trying, and keep trying, until you finally triumph. And you will retry. A lot.Only one other game has ever made me more frustrated than this (you’ll keep, Dark Souls). I’d have the final powerup, rainbow trailing behind me, knowing the end is near, only to miss-time an easy jump and go all the way back to the start. My desk is not fist-pound rated, but it should be. What makes it frustrating, is that on paper, it is so simple. All it is, is timing and reflexes and knowing the right inputs. There’s no other tactics that that. But the timing here can be unforgiving.Makes it all the better when you do finally complete a level you were stuck on forever.This is the best of the Bit.Trip series; if you want to start somewhere, this is the game to buy.

Posted: June 28, 2012
												The Good: Addictive 2D platforming at its finest, charming visuals and audio, responsive controls, great level designThe Bad: Can be very frustrating in later levels, only one audio track, casual gamers may quite early onRhythm games may not be all the rage anymore the unique ones really stick out. You can’t pick your own songs, there’s no fancy instruments, it’s just you and the controller/keyboard jumping to make a good techno beat. The idea of the game is to get through each of the three worlds through 12 levels each while jumping, kicking, and sliding your way through the level. If you get hit just once you reset back to the very beginning. While on the early levels this is fine the later ones take up to 4 minutes or more to complete so getting reset is so frustrating.Obstacles range from blocks you have to jump over, low hanging objects to slide under, stairs that require quick taps, and even some stop to fool you like a bouncing cube which one you slide under and one you jump over. There are spring pads and other obstacles to block your path, but precise timing will be required to get all the gold blocks to get to the bonus stages which are 8 bit variations of the 16 bit/3D levels. It’s very unique, charming, and extremely addictive and fun. I am currently stuck on 1-11 and have been for weeks, but I keep going at it because I just want to play every level.The music is pretty good and full of life despite it being the same track through each level. During parts of the level you will pick up a giant plus sign that will add tracks to the beat and it also adds to the visuals. BIT.TRIP is really a game for casual players and hardcore platformers who miss the days of the 16/8 bit era. The game has brilliant level design that adds a lot of challenge while still being manageable. I haven’t really played a 2D platformer this addictive in years.The visuals are stunning with wonderful 16 bit to 3D translation and the game has a wide color palette that sticks to the 16 bit and 8 bit era. Everything is made of blocks, but is built in 3D and can really be a mind trip some times especially when you first start playing. Don’t let the hard levels keep you from playing because being able to play the later levels is rewarding and challenging. I highly recommend this game to any 2D platformer or even for someone just looking for a fun arcade game.--Score: 8.5/10

Posted: January 12, 2014
												Stay away from this game. It's a good example of poor game design.The core idea is fine; it's a runner-style game, not unlike others of the genre. The good distinguishing things that it has are the art style (it looks like an Atari game) and the music. As you evade obstacles and grab items, it adds to the music in interesting ways. Sometimes, you can use musical patterns to help you determine when you should jump. It's a nice, unique touch.The problem is that the game demands perfection, and requires trial-and-error and memorization in order to achieve it. If you die (get hit by an object, run into something, or fall in a pit), you're sent back to the beginning of the level. There are a number of cheap deaths to be found, where you can't realistically be expected to foresee or react to a threat quickly enough to survive it. This means you'll have to die repeatedly while you discover these points and memorize them, until you reach a point where you can clear a level. Many of these spots require pinpoint precision, and a few levels are particularly infuriating for their great length.Perfection's a fine goal, but it shouldn't be what's required in order to play or enjoy a game. If Rock Band ended a song as soon as you missed one note, no one would play it. That's essentially what this game does, and it ruins what could have been a pleasant pixelated romp.(Note: The sequel is MUCH better, correcting most of the major problems that the first game had. If you're interested, go check that out instead.)

Posted: June 18, 2015
												I really don't enjoy this game.  I feel that this game uses 8-bit aesthetics in all of the worst ways, it caves to every shortcoming that comes with being #8bit but it follows no rules, particularly none of the rules that make those games beautiful.  I feel the music prides itself on being retro, but the only genuinely retro part of the soundtrack are two the menu and credits music by Anamanaguchi (a far cry from the Scott Pilgrim game).  The actual game music feels like it's barely there, sparsely composed poppy sounding nonsense that consitutes player influenced music by it's vapidity alone.  This isn't Rez, it doesn't feel compelling become one with the music and the environment it creates, adding to a great whole.  You feel like a program playing what little gameplay is there, and it essentially comes down to being an incredibly stiff rhythm game.  And a rhythm game it is not, it sullies the concept of rhythm games by having none of the compelling parts of a rhyth game.  Think of something like Dance Dance Revolution, or beatmania in particular.  Huge skill ceiling that offers an endless climb for the skill of the player, a wide variety of fully realized music by a variety of different artists that satisfy a broad variety of taste, and an interesting and fulfilling input that gives the player variety while achieving game flow.  Runner maybe accomplishes flow, but not in a way you can't find in dozens of free games on the App Store, and those feel much more appropriate.  This may seem severly negative but Bit.Trip Runner outright fails in a lot of areas I really require more of from an experience that I don't just like, but not actively unenjoy.

Posted: May 28, 2013
												BIT.TRIP RUNNER is a fun little musical platformer. Unfortunately, the game has several problems. For one, Gaijin Games doesn't seem to know about the concept of a proper difficulty curve. The difficulty is all over the place. Some levels are hard, some levels are easy, and some levels are just disproportionately hard. Odyssey is one level that comes to mind, as several people haven't even gone past that level, if you check the achievements page. Another problem is that this game is only fun if you are good at it. Otherwise, it's just frustrating. And even if you are doing well, making one little mistake forces you to start the entire level over, which can be incredibly frustrating if it was a long level, and just plain disheartening if you keep making mistakes in a level. And one of the more glaring flaws, is how bonus levels are handled. You get to those after getting all the gold in a level. Unfortunately, you only have one try at them. If you fail, and want to try again to perfect the level, you have to play through the regular level all over again, just to get one shot at the bonus. Overall, it's a really unforgiving game.Now some of you may be thinking, "What are you talking about? The game's pretty forgiving, it gives you 11 checkpoints in one level! Quit whining!" I've heard that argument before. I am aware of how the other BIT.TRIP games work, but those games had room for error. You were allowed to make more than one mistake, and you didn't have to start a particular section over if you did. And some of you may be arguing that all this challenge and unforgiveness is just reminiscent of retro games. I suppose you could make that argument, but there's a reason why most modern games don't pull off what's done in this game, and those games were made in a time where game designers didn't really know any better, or had different ideas about what made games challenging.I suppose if you're one of those gamers that can tolerate ridiculously hard games, or are one of those people that think modern games are too easy, and are looking for challenging games, you'll probably feel right at home with this, or heck, the entire series. If you're not one of those people, you may want to skip over this title.

Posted: February 19, 2015
												Personal Enjoyment: 5/10Standalone Rating: 6/10General Rating: 8/10I really, really wish Steam had a "conditional" rating.BIT.TRIP RUNNER is the fourth entry in the BIT.TRIP franchise, and the first that I played. You play Commander Video, an alien humanoid who crashes onto an odd planet. The goal of the game is to run to the end of the level while dodging hazards and acquiring gold. Getting the gold is optional, but getting all of it lets you play a bonus stage at the end of the level. The game is divided into three zones, each of which contains twelve levels, the last of which functions as a boss fight of sorts. The story isn't of note unless you've played the whole series.The big clencher in my decision to recommend this is the difficulty. If you hit an obstacle, you are forced to start at the beginning of the level. This isn't a problem for most levels, as the obstacles don't get too tough early on and most levels last around a minute. However, certain parts of the game feel downright frustrating (1-11, for instance, has only been beaten by around 13.9% of game owners as of writing) as the level of reflex demanded climbs higher and higher. At times, it feels less like I'm getting better at the game and more like I'm memorizing the level's patterns.If you're the patient sort who likes games requiring reflex or just wants to experience the series, I'd get this game on sale. Otherwise, I'd stay away.

Posted: February 6, 2014
												Although extremely hard, this game is a ton of fun.  The platforming has to be perfect or you are done and starting the level over.  This can at times move over from fun to frustration, but the frustration is never at the game, just yourself as it is always completely fair.  Every time I try a level again I felt like I was steadily getting better, which is a good feeling.  The way the game plays to the beat is especially engaging.  As the level starts there is just a minimal framework of the music present.  As you progress through the level different elements of the song get thrown in as you pick up items and by the end of the level all of the aspects of music are there in all their glory.  This can really make you feel awesome as you get close to the end of a challenging level and the song is going in full swing.  The music is great and the building up mechanic of the music never seems to get old for me.  Definently worth putting some time into.  I really enjoy my time with this game.

Posted: March 2, 2014
												Aka: OH GOD WHY DO I GET SO ANGRY WHEN I FAIL?Bit.Trip Runner is the third in the Bit.Trip series, which makes a break from convention of the previous two. This time, you actually play as Commander Video in a side-scrolling platformer. The screen moves at a cracking pace while you run constantly in a 3D retro 8-bit inspired world. Your basic functions are to jump, slide, and kick your way around/through obstacles, while collecting gold and powerups, to reach the finish line at each stage.While this seems simple enough, and it is easy early on, it quickly delves into devious territory, requiring the utmost attention and rhythm. As with the previous Bit.Trip titles, the gameplay is heavily dependent on the music. As you collect powerups, the music becomes more and more intense, so you know after a few of them (and when that glorious rainbow trails behind you), you’re close to the end. It’s often much easier to time your jumps with the music, rather than looking at when obstacles are coming up.But if you fail; fall down a gap, hit a wall, etc, it immediately carries you all the way back to the beginning, and starts straight away in that dull pre-powerup music. It’s incredibly demoralising, to know that you were so close, only to go right back to the start music. Particularly on the longer levels (damn you, Odyssey).Because of the instant reload times, much like Super Meat Boy (who also gets a sneaky cameo), it forces you to keep trying, and keep trying, until you finally triumph. And you will retry. A lot.Only one other game has ever made me more frustrated than this (you’ll keep, Dark Souls). I’d have the final powerup, rainbow trailing behind me, knowing the end is near, only to miss-time an easy jump and go all the way back to the start. My desk is not fist-pound rated, but it should be. What makes it frustrating, is that on paper, it is so simple. All it is, is timing and reflexes and knowing the right inputs. There’s no other tactics that that. But the timing here can be unforgiving.Makes it all the better when you do finally complete a level you were stuck on forever.This is the best of the Bit.Trip series; if you want to start somewhere, this is the game to buy.

Posted: June 16, 2015
												BIT.TRIP RUNNER is as swanky and cool as a game can be. It doesn't bother with any of that garbage like story or graphics and instead focuses on teh two things that gaming is about; controls and music.You play the role of Comander Video and you contrinually stride forward dodging the caterpillaers, spikes, cranes campfires, minecarts and other♥♥♥♥♥♥in your way. The slick moves at your disposal are all you need to confront these challegnes but you'll soon realise that there's a rad beat to it all. This game doesn't throw crap at your randomly, it throws random crap at you methodically and you'll add to the soundtrack as you go. Get a clean run and the music has turned all chillaxed to reflect the zen state you find yourself in and the feeling of crossing the line after collecting all the gold in any level is almost as satisfying as the feeling of ejaculating into a warm ♥♥♥♥♥♥ or scoring the winning goal in the dying seconds of the big game. Because that's what this is; a big game that fills you with emotion whenever you play.The only negative thing I can say about this game is that each world is marred by a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ boss fight at the end. These are awful and you'll hate yourself.If your a no rythym loser who can't dance then this game isn't for you but if you're a groovy cat like me this is as good as gaming gets.

Posted: March 13, 2015
												BIT.TRIP RUNNER is a rhythm based endless runner by Gaijin games which has spawned a sequel and a whole bunch of spinoffs. I personally didn't really enjoy the game. It's simply not very fun to play. It's definitely challenging and according to the statistics less than 1/3 of players ever beat the first world. In the games detriment, I get the feeling that's because people have realized by that point that the game isn't fun enough to try to beat rather than the game being too hard. The rhythm aspect of the game might make it more enjoyable if the music were better, but frankly the music does little to improve the game. It's not a terrible game, seeing as its highly polished and feature complete but I wouldn't really reccomend it to anyone unless you really love endless runners.

Posted: September 19, 2013
												Bit.trip Runner is a beat/platforming game starring Commander Video. Controls start out simple enough with the first couple levels consisting of just jumping. Then the levels get a little harder adding sliding, then super jumps, then kicking, then blocking.  By the 6th or 7th level you are jumping, sliding and kicking over under and thorugh obstacles to the beat, and if you fail, back to the start. This can be soo frustrating at times, getting through 80% of a level and having to go back to the very beginning but when you do beat it, it just makes it that much better. One of the harder beat games I've ever played along with other Bit.trip titles. The kind of game that once you beat it you will have no desire to play anytime in the near future. 8/10

Posted: January 19, 2014
												A challenging rhythm/platformer that should keep you entertained for a few hours.Runner is a bit of a weird game, not really being a platformer, but not exactly a rhythm game in the traditional sense. Instead, you have to think of jumps as notes that you have to anticipate and hit at the right note, with collectibles and gold littered across the levels extra notes that make a more layered track. The fact is, that's exactly what happens and it makes for a great game when every sound is bleeping and blooping at you in harmony. Of course, it's not that simple.The challenge is getitng the rhythm right, unsurprisingly. Whilst on the whole there's a very good difficulty curve, there are the odd speed-bumps in certain levels, or certain sections in certain levels, that may prohibit you from progression or from getting that last collectible you need to 100% a level. It's this challenge though that drives you to not making do with simply passing the level and thus provides the bulk of time spent playing the game.The result is that certain levels can invoke that sense of you moving forward inch-by-inch as you clear one jump, only to fail on the next one, forcing you to replay through the rest of the level once, twice, however many times until you get that one section right. Sometimes this is okay, sometimes it can be frustrating, probably dependent on whether or not you're going for 100% or not.At the end of the day though, it's a fun game with a vivid visual presentation and some great audio that offers some pretty satisfying challenge in gameplay that's a little bit different.

Posted: January 12, 2014
												Stay away from this game. It's a good example of poor game design.The core idea is fine; it's a runner-style game, not unlike others of the genre. The good distinguishing things that it has are the art style (it looks like an Atari game) and the music. As you evade obstacles and grab items, it adds to the music in interesting ways. Sometimes, you can use musical patterns to help you determine when you should jump. It's a nice, unique touch.The problem is that the game demands perfection, and requires trial-and-error and memorization in order to achieve it. If you die (get hit by an object, run into something, or fall in a pit), you're sent back to the beginning of the level. There are a number of cheap deaths to be found, where you can't realistically be expected to foresee or react to a threat quickly enough to survive it. This means you'll have to die repeatedly while you discover these points and memorize them, until you reach a point where you can clear a level. Many of these spots require pinpoint precision, and a few levels are particularly infuriating for their great length.Perfection's a fine goal, but it shouldn't be what's required in order to play or enjoy a game. If Rock Band ended a song as soon as you missed one note, no one would play it. That's essentially what this game does, and it ruins what could have been a pleasant pixelated romp.(Note: The sequel is MUCH better, correcting most of the major problems that the first game had. If you're interested, go check that out instead.)

Posted: January 5, 2015
												This game is like a paradox. The more frustrated you get, the harder each level is to beat, and that just makes you even more frustrated. I've commonly found the best way to beat a level is to quit and come back to it later... often I can get it on the first try, no matter how difficult I'd found it before. It's a game you love to keep coming back to and I've played for hours (often in offline mode, hence my play time).Bit.Trip Runner is an extremely difficult game, but it hooks you with catchy music that will leave you mumbling motions under your breath ("kick. jump, down, jump. kick kick jump down jump kick"). Your curses at each loss (which all catapult you to the beginning of the level) will not be quite so quiet. If you're used to playing normal difficulty at other games, I recommend playing easy on this one, and don't try the most difficult setting unless you are a god. 8/10 would not buy for the full price simply because the game is so frustrating and simplistic, but would pick it up on sale any day of the week.

												Why I bought the game: BundleWhat I liked about the game: This was one of my first indie bundle games that sat in my library for a while collecting dust. I am glad I tried it out, it's a simple game, you have a few commands, jump, kick, slide - what makes the game fun and not just some lame jump side scroll is the perpetual movement, mixed with positive reinforcement with sound activated moments upon collecting certain items. This is an awesome tablet or phone game as well, easy to pick up and let go, overall I love BIT TRIP and it's become a staple game for steam for me. What I didn't like about the game: The game is not easy, this isn't a bad thing - it just gets frustrating, so if you get frustrated easily this game is not for you. Would I buy at current asking price of 9.99? It's cuyrrently on sale for .99 cents, which is normally is on sale or found in bundles. It's worth a play for a sale price.**Disclaimer**I would like to state all changes made by the developers of the game after this review could potentially make this entire review irrelevant. Posted: March 25, 2012
												Bit. Trip Runner offers an excellent running experience with a high grain of difficulty. Players control Commander Video, the black sprite as he ventures through the world. Story is very minimal, with a few cutscenes at the start of each world and for the ending. The blocky art style transfers into 3d, where objects feel as if they could fit in a retro game. The music is superb, using chiptune and contemporary electronic music to provide beats while playing, making for dynamic music. A few songs by Anamanaguchi add to the experience. The first world is not too hard, but the later levels provide much pain yet also a refreshing change in appearance and music. I've had issues with a couple tough levels in all 3 worlds but muscled through to the end. In addition to simple running and jumping, more complex commands and obstacles are added to put difficulty and spice to the mix. The toughness of the game may be a turnoff, but the graphics and music create a love for the older era of games.

												Really enjoyable rhythm runner. My biggest problem with the game is at times the levels seemed to be trial and error focused. By that I mean you have to lose repeatedly and get a little further every time until you have the level memorized. A few levels are disproportionately more difficult than the others. On the plus side, this means beating the entire game is extremely satisfying.  Aside from that the chiptune music is excellent, the graphics are charming, and despite difficulty spikes the game is addictive.For what it's worth by comparison Bit.Trip Presents Runner 2... is a lot easier and a lot less satisfying to complete than its predecessor.  If you want a real reflex challenge, then try this one out.

												If you're a fan of hard-as-nails games, like Super Meat Boy and Super Hexagon, this is a must. It's a Minimalist 2-D puzzle-rhythm hybrid.Pros:+ Simple 2-D Design+ Music is nice+ Great controlCons:- Exceptionally hard- Patience is required- Music CAN get on your nerves very easily.Overall, it's a very good game if you're looking for a very good challenge, and it has a great soundtrack. Posted: May 28, 2013
												BIT.TRIP RUNNER is a fun little musical platformer. Unfortunately, the game has several problems. For one, Gaijin Games doesn't seem to know about the concept of a proper difficulty curve. The difficulty is all over the place. Some levels are hard, some levels are easy, and some levels are just disproportionately hard. Odyssey is one level that comes to mind, as several people haven't even gone past that level, if you check the achievements page. Another problem is that this game is only fun if you are good at it. Otherwise, it's just frustrating. And even if you are doing well, making one little mistake forces you to start the entire level over, which can be incredibly frustrating if it was a long level, and just plain disheartening if you keep making mistakes in a level. And one of the more glaring flaws, is how bonus levels are handled. You get to those after getting all the gold in a level. Unfortunately, you only have one try at them. If you fail, and want to try again to perfect the level, you have to play through the regular level all over again, just to get one shot at the bonus. Overall, it's a really unforgiving game.Now some of you may be thinking, "What are you talking about? The game's pretty forgiving, it gives you 11 checkpoints in one level! Quit whining!" I've heard that argument before. I am aware of how the other BIT.TRIP games work, but those games had room for error. You were allowed to make more than one mistake, and you didn't have to start a particular section over if you did. And some of you may be arguing that all this challenge and unforgiveness is just reminiscent of retro games. I suppose you could make that argument, but there's a reason why most modern games don't pull off what's done in this game, and those games were made in a time where game designers didn't really know any better, or had different ideas about what made games challenging.I suppose if you're one of those gamers that can tolerate ridiculously hard games, or are one of those people that think modern games are too easy, and are looking for challenging games, you'll probably feel right at home with this, or heck, the entire series. If you're not one of those people, you may want to skip over this title.

BIT.TRIP RUNNER is the fourth game in the BIT.TRIP game series, starting with BEAT and ending with FLUX. Posted: June 21, 2014
												This game is full of charm and always manages to put a smile on my face. It's a simple platformer game on rails. You jump, slide, kick and spring your way through each stage, broken up into levels with a boss at the end to the infectious beats provided by the games' addictive soundtrack. Gold coins are scattered throughout each level, collecting them all gives you access to a bonus round if you make it to the end of the level. Bonus rounds are retro-stylised versions of the main game where you play for extra points to improve your high score.Death in BIT.TRIP.RUNNER is caused by hitting any obstacle, be it a knee-high ledge you were supposed to jump over or a UFO you needed to slide under. The best feature this game posseses is that, upon death you don't face loading screens or some mocking text, you are visually dragged back to the start of the level to instantly resume in the fun, this makes death (almost) painless and doesn't break the flow of your gaming.I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys video-games but perhaps not to those who detest the sort of precise gameplay that BIT.TRIP.RUNNER demands in its latter levels.

												A really addictive side scroller that combines 3D surroundings with a 2D character which works very well. The music changes depending upon how you progress in the levels which adds uniqueness to the game itself. Simple gameplay mechanics build up upon each other to create quite an intresting little indie game which can be played for long periods of time due to the need to finish levels regardless of how many times you fail. Keeps the player drawn in and is a well executed game overall.

Posted: September 21, 2011
												Think you have good reflexes?  I won't tell you otherwise, but this game will.  Your pattern memorization and quick thinking skills must be at their best in order to beat this game.  It's all about flow.  Run through beautiful 8-bit environments, and perform actions according to the exciting music which gets more intense as you progress through the level.  Oh, and make it through each level without messing up, or you have to start over, try it out.
